item.name: 10 Days in Africa
item.comment: I miss the railroads and the ships of 10 Days is Asia. Much easier to win in this version. I do like the Jeeps. Still love this series, 10 Days is Asia is still my preferred version.

item.name: 10 Days in Asia
item.comment: Wow! Fell in love with this game after 1 play. It fit all the perfect sweet spots for me and my wife now that we have young kids--quick play time, interesting strategy, great theme, and can be educational for the kids when they're older. Will be looking into the others of the series.

item.name: 10 Days in Europe
item.comment: I enjoy this one more than 10 Days in Africa--the board is more varied and interesting, but not as much as 10 Days in Asia. Love this series, and so does my wife. Great game before bed.

item.name: 1313 Dead End Drive
item.comment: There is something morbidly engrossing about splattering the assorted heirs with statue, chandelier, and bank vault pig, as well as flinging heirs off the stairs and into the fireplace. The 3-D board while cartoony adds much to the theme. The gameplay is unbalanced, leading to heirs hanging around the kill zone in order to collect cards to kill them. House rules and variants make this game much more interesting. My wife and I pull it out every few months for some relatively mindless fun. For us,this is a keeper until the components give out from overuse.

item.name: 22 Ku-du
item.comment: Math game, which is a rip-off sudoku. In scrabble style,place the number tiles into rows so they add up to 22. I can see this being a math teaching tool, but as for fun? The one bright spot is that it comes in a portable zipper bag for easy travel. Not my kind of game at all. My wife does enjoy this a few times a year, so we keep it around.

item.name: 221B Baker Street: The Master Detective Game
item.comment: This really isn't a very good deduction/mystery game, yet I find myself enjoying it anyway. The gameboard makes for repetitive gameplay as certain areas are always investigated first. The mysteries usually revolve around wordgames and not actual Holmes like deduction. My wife and I pull it out about once a year and will probably keep it until we finish all 80 mysteries (we have the booster packs) or die of old age, whichever comes first.

item.name: 4 Player Chess
item.comment: I actually enjoyed 4-player chess more than regular chess, but it was nearly impossible to get anyone to play.

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment: After my first play, this game continued to grow on me. I found the player interaction and resource management fascinating. There is a learning curve for new players due to all the symbols, but once that's mastered the game plays very fast. I would have enjoyed it more if I had some time to explore the cards, instead of being thrust into the game by other players. The different paths to victory (military, scientific, buildings) keep the strategy interesting, as well as the the numerous leaders and the 7 different wonders themselves. I may have to pick this one up.

item.name: Ablaze!
item.comment: Mechanics are good, but to simple of a game. Theme is pasted on. Wanted to like, as a solo playing forest fire fighting game has much appeal to me (done that job before). This one didn't grab me.

item.name: Agent Hunter
item.comment: Good quick deduction game. After playing one, wanted to play another.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment: I really enjoy this game. The strategy of every game is always a little different based on your Occupation and Improvement cards. This plays very well as a 2-player game, and when I play it with more, the game feels completely different because of the new cards in play. I understand how the theme may not appeal to some, but for Erin and me, it works beautifully.

item.name: Alchemist
item.comment: There is more here than it appears. Instead of the theme overcoming its components, this felt like a trading in cubes for different cubes games. Neat concept. Hard to decipher a clear strategy. I'd play again, but it's not high on my list.

item.name: Alienz
item.comment: While this is not a great game, it is a good game. The gameplay is orginial, the artowrk interesting (if childish), and there's a fair amount of strategy.

item.name: Allegro
item.comment: I love classical music, but I never figured out this game.

item.name: Among the Stars
item.comment: Was everything I hoped and expected. So many cards keep it interesting and fresh. I like the building of the space station. Good game.

item.name: Among the Stars: Ambassadorial Shuttle
item.comment: A single card promo.

item.name: Among the Stars: Hythian
item.comment: Anther Race? Okay.

item.name: Among the Stars: Indiegogo Promos
item.comment: More stuff. Yum.

item.name: Among the Stars: Pre-order Promo Cards
item.comment: More stuff. Yum.

item.name: Among the Stars: Section Seal
item.comment: Single card. Neat idea. Like it.

item.name: Among the Stars: Stretch Rewards
item.comment: More stuff to organize, but it's all good.

item.name: Among the Stars: The Ambassadors
item.comment: Nice expansion to add another element to the game.

item.name: Among the Stars: Wiss
item.comment: Another race. Score.

item.name: Anachronism
item.comment:
Complete First Set Minus demo warriors (Beowulf & dal Miyamoto Musashi)
Spartacus, Canute, Achilles, Hercules, Alexander opened Rest of warriors and support decks unopened.
item.conditiontext: 2/3 of expansion packs unopened in mint condition

item.name: Android: Netrunner
item.comment: Not my style of game--card heavy, direct confrontation. I enjoy the theme, and like the asymmetrical style of play. Huge learning curve to play and learn the lingo. Hate having to know every single card in your deck and/or building decks to try to beat some one. I see the appeal, but not for me.

item.name: Animal Upon Animal
item.comment: Great for kids. High quality components. Fun to play with the wooden animals when not playing the game. Highly recommended.

item.name: Apples to Apples
item.comment: This is one of the very few games my father has ever requested to play. For this reason alone, it ranks high. While I can understand that this game can become monotonous if played frequently, when enjoyed a few times a year, I always find it refreshing. As everyone receives a turn at being the judge, everyone can provide their own unique slant to the game.

item.name: Apples to Apples Party Box Expansion TWO
Apples to Apples to Go
item.comment: Expansion to Apples to Apples that just gives more of the same. Nothing unusual here.

item.name: Archaeology: The Card Game
item.comment: Nice quick card game. Got this for my mom who studied archaeology in college. It plays fast, has some strategy and a good theme, and several folks in my family enjoy it. A keeper. My copy was missing one Broken Cup card, but it hasn't really caused any problems.

item.name: Arkham Horror
item.comment: There are few games I've fallen in love with as much as Arkham Horror. The theme, the setting, the monsters, the psychological horror, the locations, the characters, the replayability. Who isn't terrified of the Great Old Ones? For games that play long 3-5 hours, this one is the top of the list. I know this isn't for everyone, but for some good old storytelling and monster trashing, nothing beats this game. Ia! Ia! Ia!

item.name: Arkham Horror: Dunwich Horror Expansion
item.comment: The Injury and Madness cards along make this expansion well worth getting. I really enjoy how the expansion board relates to the original board. The Dunwich Horror ratchets up the tension, but not so much that the game is unwinnable. First expansion I would recommend folks to get.

item.name: Arkham Horror: Innsmouth Horror Expansion
item.comment: Not quite as tight as Dunwich, but I do love the water monsters and movement. You're looking at little odd... Sister Mary... Sister Mary? Run Ashcan Pete! She has the Innsmouth Look!

item.name: Arkham Horror: Kingsport Horror Expansion
item.comment: This seems to receive less love than the other Big Box expansions. I enjoyed it very much. The closing of the rifts by visiting locations greatly appeals to me. I also enjoy the new GOOs and characters.

item.name: Arkham Horror: Miskatonic Horror Expansion
item.comment: Really like this expansion. More cards for the 3 big box expansions? Yes please! It fills out the decks nicely. The institutions are an interesting addition though I don't know how much I'll use them. An expansion for expansion? Held off for a while, but very glad I got this.

item.name: Arkham Horror: The Black Goat of the Woods Expansion
item.comment: This Arkham Horror expansion ratchets up the difficulty to an absurd amount. My wife and I have hardly won any games played. All the new decks make this far more fiddly then other expansions, and you keep having to remember a dozen different things--oh, yeah, that corrupted my ability for this, wait no, it was that. Of the handful of expansions I've played so far, this is my least favorite. Boy this makes me sick of Dark Young!

item.name: Arkham Horror: The King in Yellow Expansion
item.comment: I love the theme of this small-box expansion. It seems to fit so well into the base Arkham Horror Game. Definitely will play with this expansion frequently.

item.name: Asking for Trobils
item.comment: This game did play 7 players well. Gameplay is simple (2 actions a turn--place ship or take ship back). Where you place that ship is the crux. If you can get other players to "bump" your ship back" you'll get more turns and have an advantage. Game can promote Analysis Paralysis. Game has a good sense of humor. Color Scheme is awful. Enjoyed my first play. Wouldn't request this, but wouldn't turn it down either.

item.name: At the Gates of Loyang
item.comment: The wooden vegetable bits are really fantastic. Though basically a card game, the bits really bring the theme to life. My wife really likes the farming theme, and the marketplace interplay keeps things interesting. There's plenty to keep a gamer's interest if they enjoy the theme.

item.name: Attika
item.comment: While the gameplay is interesting, and I enjoy the Greek buildings and theme, the flimsy components detract significantly from this game. One of the few games I've been disappointed with after purchasing. I've mainly only played this with two players and I suspect it's more interesting with more.

item.name: Australia
item.comment: Area control game--rangers fly in to make improvement in the different Australian subsections or protect environmental aspects. Nice colorful board. The game gets a few plays, but not high on the list. Probably more fun with more players, but only played with 2. Would also have been more interesting when I was a kid.

item.name: Australian Rails
item.comment: One of my favorite in the crayon-railway games. The map of Australia just appeals to me. The spread of resources and cities plays nicely, and it seems to be a quicker play than others. Highly enjoyable version.

item.name: Automobile
item.comment: Well designed and crafted game that mimics the audo industry very well. Not so many different things going on as to be chaotic, but enough choices and mindgames to really make you think about every decision. Not one I need to own, but would definitely play again.

item.name: Avalanche
item.comment: Game from my childhood of dropping marbles down a shoot, with levers bouncing back and fourth as marbles fall. It was lots of fun as a kid, though I have no recollection of gameplay.

item.name: Axis & Allies
item.comment: First really serious game. So much going on here. Love the strategy of the different sides. Pieces are great. This is a good 2-player introductory wargame, but it is not for my wife. Also it doesn't have a lot of frequent play vale because the setup is always the same. Still, a keeper, one I pull out solo about once a year to enjoy the strategy.

item.name: Back to the Future: The Card Game
item.comment: Just a version of Chrononauts. Movie Theme works well. Wife like this, but I wouldn't suggest it. Better than Chononauts--this version fixed some of the issues with the original.

item.name: Balderdash
item.comment: Loved this game about 15 years ago, before BGG. Often would play it without the game and with a dictionary. Now, I've never pulled it out, as if I have a group large enough, I reach for something else. Still enjoy, just not a favorite anymore.

item.name: Bananagrams
item.comment: If you like word games, this is a great crossword puzzle building game. Plays quick and nice components. Recommended to those who enjoy word games.

item.name: The Barbarossa Campaign
item.comment: Good game. I'm just starting to delve into solo wargames. Really enjoy this solo gem. Its a wargame that doesn't feel the same. There's enough variability to keep it interesting. The chit-pull system is a neat system that changes throughout the game. This is a struggle. It does take a while, and the component quality is low. A nice reproduction with great components would send this game through the roof. Highly recommended for solo wargamers.

item.name: The Battle at Kemble's Cascade
item.comment: Neat board game implementation of an old scrolling computer game. However, there's a ton of work to pull this off. Why not just go plan it on the computer? Still, I enjoyed it. Don't need to own, but enjoyed my play of it.

item.name: Battlelords CCG
item.comment: Not a fan of CCGs. This is a clunky one. It's too bad because I love the Battlelords universe (have often played the RPG), and this would make a great CCG or boardgame, and we have neither.

item.name: Battleship
item.comment: This old game has its simplistic charm. While there's a fair amount of luck, there is some strategy, which is especially good for kids to learn. I really don't mind playing this. I look forward to playing this with the kids.

item.name: Battleship: Hidden Threat
item.comment: Much more interesting game than regular Battleship. The adaptations of special ship abilities and defense cards makes for more interesting strategy. Plays quick, about 15 minutes. Another decent braindead evening/filler card game.

item.name: Battlestar Galactica: Pegasus Expansion
item.comment: Enjoyable Expansion for a fantastic basegame. Recommended. I like how Pegasus is incorporated.

item.name: Battling Tops
item.comment: I know this game as Battling Spaceships. Gameplay is horrid (spin the spinner and move), but who doesn't love pulling the strings and watching the spaceships (tops) collide? Great fun with kids.

item.name: Bazaar
item.comment: Interesting trading game. It's a good well thought out game, but the theme is not strong enough for me. It's too abstract. Totally worth the few bucks I paid at a thrift store, but not something I would ever have bought full price.
item.conditiontext: Box has where, but interior components were never played. Cards and tokens were still in shrink. Now been opened and played a few times.

item.name: Betrayal at House on the Hill
item.comment: My kind of game. Like exploration, the characters, the traitor. Neat how the story changes based on the tile explored when an omen check fails. But, it needs a nice upgrade--components are boring and uninspired, detracts from the game. The rules are vague which slows the game down. But, I would definitely play more.

item.name: Beyond Balderdash
item.comment: Love this game, but just never hits the table. Was happy to give this away on the thrift list. Will probably pickup again if I find it at a thrift store.

item.name: Big Boggle
item.comment: I love good word games, and my love for this game stretches back to childhood. However, a few year stint of the online version catapulted me into an insane level. My wife likes playing this, but we mutually agreed not to count it in our statistics, because of the supremely unbalanced nature of victories.

item.name: Bingo
item.comment: What do you think? It's bingo. I don't know if I'll ever understand the appeal of bingo for the retired crowd. This is the definition of boring. The version I have a Xmas gift, and my kids enjoy it, so I keep it for now.

item.name: Blockhead!
item.comment: Dexterity game enjoyable as a kid. It's basically the more popular Animal Upon Animal (which I own) before it existed. No need to play today.

item.name: Blokus
item.comment: I've always loved geometric games, all the way back to shapes in elementary school. This scratches that itch perfectly and can be played solo. The colors also nicely complement each other. Kids like playing with these pieces.

item.name: Blokus 3D
item.comment: Played this as Rumis. I enjoyed teh 3D geometry building of the game, but no one else I played it with enjoyed it much.

item.name: Blokus Duo
item.comment: Blokus specifically designed for two. Game works great. Color scheme is dreadful.

item.name: Blokus Trigon
item.comment: Blokus with triangles instead of squares. New shape structures create new strategies. If you like Blokus, you'll like Blokus Trigon. Very pleased I picked this up in a Math Trade.

item.name: Blue Moon
item.comment: I'm just not a deck-building gamer. The artwork was nice, but I'd rather play so many other games. Traded my copy away.

item.name: Boggle
item.comment: I can't help but love Boggle. I played this as a means for creativity when I was actively writing for a few years. When I needed a break, I played boggled online. Not only was it a good break, it drastically improved my typing skills.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment:
Decent card game. Plays ok with 2 players. The Bean theme didn't really appeal to to me or my wife. Will give it another play to see if our opinion improves. There's nothing wrong with this game, and we like many of this designer's games, but we'd rather play other games.
On Second play, opinion holds. Artwork turns us off. Rather play other card games.

item.name: Booktastic!
item.comment: Dreadful. Roll and move trivia game that defines tedium. Nothing about this game worked. Ugh. Stay away.

item.name: Bootleggers
item.comment: Good game. Lots of strategy and conniving against other players. This game is mean though, and folks should now it ahead of time--stealing cards, killing off influence, getting to the speakeasies first. Bootlegger's theme is great. The Kickstarter was okay--on the expensive side, and it seemed like they could have done more. Different trucks instead of one mold? Trucks that fit the required number of crates? Still, a good game.

item.name: Bootleggers: Thug Promo
item.comment: Just a small promo to include with the game. Nothing fancy.

item.name: Brass
item.comment: There's a lot going on here. I enjoy the theme, which quite surprised me--it is rather historically stuffy, yet it works. Too deep for my group or wife. Was never going to hit the table.

item.name: Break the Safe
item.comment: Nice cooperative kids game, one of the original. The timer counting down adds much tension. Won't play this often until the kids are oldest enough to enjoy, but this is one of the few decent mass-produced Matel games in existence.
item.conditiontext: Found this at a Thirft Store, in decent condition, the day I received this from a fellow thrifter (free save for shipping). Now I unexpectedly have 2 copies. The copy that was sent to me is complete and in excellent shape. Yay! The thrifted copy is in decent shape, (some box issues, torn corner, tape, crush damage). Missing the 1 pieces mentioned in the Wants Parts list.

item.name: BuyWord
item.comment:
Picked this up for my mom as it's a word game that can easily be played solo. It fills a great word game niche. The selection of letters, whether to buy or sell, adds a great strategy element to the game. If you enjoy word games this is a great option. Look forward to more plays.
2/18/15 inceased my rating. Finally got a chance to play this some more with my mom. It has easily held its appeal. If I gamed with anyone who enjoyed word games, I'd definitely recommend this.

item.name: Camelot
item.comment: Brother owned as "Inside Moves" when I was little I really enjoyed the pieces. I've discovered I'm not much of an abstract gamer these days, but this one still sits in my memory. Perhaps one day I'll try it again.
item.conditiontext: Found at a thrift store. Some crush damage, but otherwise good condition.

item.name: Candy Land
item.comment: Ugh

item.name: Captain's Wager
item.comment: Another new game. Pirates betting their treasure to try and accrue the most treasure. Was somewhat interesting. If you got high cards, it seemed like you were pretty likely to win an encounter. This luck is mitigated by playing 3 encounters per round, and at least 3 adventures, if not more.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment: My wife and I played the heck out of this game when we first acquired it about 10 years. Now we've moved on. We haven't moved on from many games, but this is one of them. I'll still gladly play it, and I even enjoy it solo. Really enjoy building the strange world. Too many expansions increase the play time to an absurd time, so you have to monitor that.

item.name: Carcassonne: Expansion 1 – Inns & Cathedrals
item.comment: Not my favorite expansion, but a decent won. Makes roads more interesting as they can be worth more points. Cathedrals can be good for being viscous against opponents-suddenly a castle can be worth no points. I always play with this expansion.

item.name: Carcassonne: Expansion 2 – Traders & Builders
item.comment: My favorite Carcassonne expansion. I like the trade goods collection--affects castle building and who claims the castle. The builder is a very strategic addition allowing an extra tile draw and placement. I always play with this expansion.

item.name: Carson City
item.comment: I enjoy this one, but don't absolutely love it. I like the duels. I like the role selection and city building. However, the game is only 4 rounds. Just when things are really starting to heat up, the game ends. It's difficult to balance money and victory points and there's quite a bit of mental meth. Still, it's a good game.

item.name: Cartagena
item.comment: I like the concept of this game. Simple, yet, some strategy. Look forward to playing more.

item.name: Castaways
item.comment:
Very thematic. I really like the exploration deck that changes throughout the game based on choices. Every game has different options based on your exploration discovery and random start-up cards. Rulebook leaves a lot of unanswered questions and its taken two games to figure out the gameplay so its smooth. Wish they had included a player aid sheet for the turn order as well as made the male/female explorers back/front on the same card. Overall, happy with it so far.
Unfortunately, this one doesn't hold up over time. Every game has been a 2-4 hour slogfest that should easily play in half the time. Some very neat ideas, details, and stories, but not enough for the length. Want to like it so much more.

item.name: Castle Panic
item.comment: Not a deep game. Kill the monsters before they kill you. 2 year old daughter loves pulling monsters out of the bag. Great game for 6-12 year olds to learn cooperative play, basic strategy planning, and the concept of inevitable defeat. Will play occasionally with my wife for some quick, relatively mindless fun. Will keep this until the kids are grown. Also a good quick solo game to play, which I know I will pull out every so often, but can see tiring of quickly.

item.name: Castle Panic: Any Color Hero Promo
Castle Panic: The Wizard's Tower
item.comment: This expansion takes a decent game, which is very good for older kids, and suddenly makes it a challenge. The diversity of monsters attacking you and the diversity of wizard cards makes the game much more interesting. Great expansion that elevates the game without changing its basic identity--the thing that every good expansion should do.

item.name: Castle Risk
item.comment: There are some interesting elements in this game, but I never enjoyed it more than regular risk. Still own it if that says anything.

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy
item.comment: A very well balanced euro. One of the best I've played. After playing Troyes (another dice management game which I did not like), I was wary of these mechanics. This game, however, totally sold the mechanic for me. I learned the game with some friends in NM, picked up the game in an auction, and now my wife and I have really enjoyed every play. The game scales very well whether for 2 or 3 or 4 players. Kudos to the game's designers.

item.name: The Castles of Burgundy: 1st Expansion – New Player Boards
The Castles of Burgundy: 4th Expansion – Monastery Boards
Castles of Mad King Ludwig
item.comment: Loved my first play. The way the castle is constructed in front you is very rewarding. Think my wife will really like it. This is also a nice quick solo puzzle, beat-the-score. It's hitting a sweet spot.

item.name: Catan
item.comment: This is a remarkable gateway game. Easy to learn and addictive. Lots of chance and easily suffers from analysis paralysis, but those negatives don't overshadow the simple fun and tension this game creates. My sister-in-law gave this to us many years ago, and it definitely elevated all of our board gaming interest to a new level. We played like 80 games of it that first year. Now, the original pales in comparison to the Seafarers expansion, which provides for the same gameplay with infinite board varieties. Still, we always introduce the original first to friends, and we've introduced numerous friends to this. A great game, especially for casual or newer gamers.

item.name: Catan: Seafarers
item.comment: Expands the base game without any major changes--ships allow water movement. Makes the Settlers of Catan infinitely replayable. One of my favorite expansions. Gave me everything I wanted and needed in the game. I've thus never felt the need to acquire any other Catan expansions.

item.name: Cathedral
item.comment: An area control game with beautiful wooden pieces. I wished my wife enjoyed it more so it would get more plays. I like to put this on end tables for display. A keeper, even with the luke-warm wife reception.

item.name: The Cave
item.comment: I'm a caver, so this game is an absolute must have. Does a great job of simulating cave exploration. I would recommend any caver get this game. I enjoy the random tile draws, and it's difficult to know who is ahead based on the end scoring. Both of those will be drawbacks to some players. This is a good game, but not a great game. Don't see mass appeal.

item.name: Chairs
item.comment: Mildly interesting stacking, dexterity game. Far more interesting than Jenga. I'll see if my daughter likes this game in a year, otherwise I'll take it to the thrift store.
item.conditiontext: Complete. Tin has tape residue, some dents.

item.name: Cheaty Mages!
item.comment: This is a fine betting game, but I the artwork is not for me, and it didn't hold my interest enough to keep. Traded away.

item.name: Checkers
item.comment: My wife and I played this the other day, and I was surprised by how much I enjoyed it, and the greater amount of strategy than I expected. Look forward to playing with the kids.

item.name: Chess
item.comment: Chess is a great game. The strategy is mind-numbing. In fact, because the best players are so fanatical about it, it really turns me off. I've never really gotten into it, though I appreciate its historical craft.

item.name: Chicken Cha Cha Cha
item.comment: Awesome kids game. Great components. The chickens are absolutely fantastic. They're huge! The pieces that form the circle and memory guessing cards are thick cardboard. Great components. The gameplay is quite clever for a memory game. Highly recommended for a kids game.

item.name: China Rails
item.comment: Nice iteration of the crayon-rail series. I enjoy learning the geography and resource placement. Keeps the other crayon-rail series we own fresh.

item.name: Chinese Checkers
item.comment: Abstracts don't do it for me any more, but this one is more enjoyable than most. Will play when asked.

item.name: The Christmas Game
item.comment:
I vaguely remember playing this game a few times when I was little. I have no idea whatever happened to it, and can't even remember the last time I saw it before moving out of the house I grew up in. It's a mystery.
It was fun as a kid, but don't think I'd play it now.
Another poster wrote: "It's a pretty typical roll-and-move set collection game. The Christmas theme means you have an excuse to bust it out once a year. Unfortunately, you need an excuse, because this travesty won't provide any of its own. Still, if you have a family of non-gamers (like I do), then these kinds of games are probably all you can get them to play."
Well said. Well said.

item.name: Chrononauts
item.comment: game just doesn't work for me at all. It needed a few more months of playtesting. It takes too much time for what it is. We play with a house rule that you have to succeed at 2 missions to win with artifacts--otherwise we always won that way and not through correcting the timeline. The game has a really neat idea, but it just falters. Perhaps it would be better with more than 2-players, because it usually turns into undoing changes to the timeline your opponent just made.

item.name: Citadels
item.comment: This is a great 2-player game (really I'd recommend this for any number), but with 2 it plays very fast. The rules are simple, but the gameplay has complex strategy and some great role-selection deduction. I'm amazed how interesting this simple design can play. Erin really enjoys this game--our second play. This became our go-to game for a few co-workers over the summer

item.name: Citadels: The Dark City
item.comment: Gives the game even more replayability, tension, choices, and fun.

item.name: Clue
item.comment: In gamer circles, there's not much to like here. Simple deduction and logic puzzle exercise. Yet this is an old-time classic that family members and nongamers always enjoy. There's something about tiny weapons, secret passages, and murder. I enjoy every so often with certain people, but not with serious gamers.

item.name: Clue Master Detective
item.comment: It's too bad this game has the clue franchise stamped on it, otherwise I think gamers would appreciate it much more. While I would not play this with more than 2-3 players, there is a heap of strategy for both investigators and the art thief. Lots of tension.

item.name: Clue Mysteries
item.comment: Thrift Store Find. Nice children's twist on Clue. Wife and I enjoy this about once a year. All the houses are quite fun to set-up and look at. It's a roll and move with more options that regular die-rolling Clue. A keeper for the kids.

item.name: Clue: The Great Museum Caper
item.comment: My wife has steadily improved her opinion of the game over the years into one where she'll play it and wants to keep it for the future. I think if this wasn't a Clue derivative, it would see more BGG love. The only thing related to clue are the character namesakes which are completely irrelevant to the gamplay. Clue: Museum Caper actually has some strategically chops and tense choices: do I steal another painting or try to leave while I can?

item.name: Colt Express
item.comment: Lots of fun with this game. I wonder how much replability this game will have. There's only so many train cars, treasures, and things you can do. I'll definitely play if requested, enjoyed my play, but think it needs more to last longer than a year. However. short length makes this a great last game of the night or shorter filler while another group finishes a longer game.

item.name: Connect Four
item.comment: I really don't mind this as a kid's game. Not for an adult, though. Picked up a thrifted copy for the kiddos. They're enjoying playing with it. Will play with them.

item.name: Conquest of Planet Earth: The Space Alien Game
item.comment: I enjoyed my first play. Nothing Earth shattering here. Move, check all the modifiers, roll dice. Repeat. Still, the theme is interesting and well implemented, I like the variable races and abilities, and I had fun. I will definitely see how it plays over time, maybe even with others and not just solo. Decent game, nothing fantastic, but a keeper for now. I do love soundtracks in Flying Frog's games.

item.name: Copycat
item.comment: Fun game. Theme of running a campaign is integrated as well as can be expected in this classic Euro game. Board and artwork are funny most of the time, but what's up with the half-naked men in so many pictures? I enjoy how the game pokes fun at many things. A good thinking Euro, but don't expect to be wowed by the theme incorporation. It mostly feels like you're playing the mechanics to win. Good game, not great, would play again.

item.name: Council of Verona
item.comment: There is a lot to think about in this game, yet I don't see myself striving to pull it out all the time. We'll see what the future holds.

item.name: The Count of Carcassonne
item.comment: Only played once. Didn't enjoy the mechanic.

item.name: Coup: Rebellion G54
item.comment: Lying and bluffing games just don't excite me very much, I hate lying to my friends even in the name of most gaming.

item.name: Crack the Case
item.comment: I really enjoyed this as a kid. Solve the riddle in 20 yes or no questions. Really interesting scenarios. Problem was that no one wanted to play it, not friends, not family. I think the cases were overly difficult. My wife might like it today.

item.name: Cribbage
item.comment: Great card game. For a while played this frequently before bed with the wife. So many levels of strategy. Definitely a card game you should learn.

item.name: Cruel Necessity
item.comment: Fascinating history. Not just a war game. The politics adds a frustratingly historical component. I like the battle format, the action points (zeal points), and flavor text. But this game is viciously hard. The achievement cards are incredibly hard to obtain. You feel like you're being crushed. It seems incredibly luck dependent to move the political tracks. Several battles should have been great victories only to roll horribly. Is this game too luck dependent? We will see. While I very much like this game. I don't know if it will have staying power because of the overwhelming luck and that hopelessness of victory..

item.name: Cthulhu Fluxx
item.comment: My wife and I do enjoy Fluxx. The was given to us from Nick. I certainly don't think we need more versions of Fluxx, yet I greatly enjoyed this theme. I've definitely fallen in love (or horror) with Lovecraftian horror.

item.name: Dancing Eggs
item.comment: Amazing amount of fun in this silly dexterity game. Running around a table? Holding eggs between different body parts? Seems stupid at first description, but it just works with any group. Kids to adults love this.

item.name: Darkest Night
item.comment:
Decent game, but not on Arkham Horror's level. Seems like it will become repetitive. Really could use "flavor text" Needs more of everything, powers, event cards, locations, characters, and changeable Necromancer abilities. Wish the characters had longer back-stories and names! I can see how the repetitive searching could become boring and annoying. Lots of promise, good design. I like it, but don't love it. Definite tension. Failure is a real possibility.
After another play, I got tired of the repetitive searching big time. Wanted to love this solo, but couldn't. Traded away.

item.name: Darkest Night: With an Inner Light
item.comment: Didn't fix the issues with the base game--repetitive nature of searching, failed roll, searching, failed roll. Sure, added more characters, and quests, but couldn't save me from trading away Darkest Night

item.name: Dead Men Tell No Tales
item.comment: Some neat aspects--the fatigue and the increased battle value, but overall, I found this too clunky and confusing to need to play more than once. Just too many good games out there, and this is average. The dice on the board ruin the pirate theme for me.

item.name: Dead of Winter: A Crossroads Game
item.comment: I enjoyed the game I played, but I don't see what all the fuss is about. Maybe I just don't enjoy Zombie games--all I've played have fallen flat for me. This is the best so far, but that's not saying much. Perhaps I would like a different scenario or two better. While this story attempts to tell a story, there are many games that do it better, usually in a short amount of time. I also don't think this game needs a betrayer element.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition)
Dinomite
item.comment: What's not to like about a boardgame with dinos? The roll and move board layout makes no sense. Cool dinos, not much else going for this game.

item.name: Dixit
item.comment: Artwork is absolutely gorgeous. Simple concept, great execution. This game breathes imagination.

item.name: Dixit Origins
item.comment: More of what is great about the base game.

item.name: Dixit Origins: "La Machine à rêves" Promotional card
item.comment: Beautiful!

item.name: Dixit Quest
item.comment: More beautiful cards.

item.name: Dixit: 2012 Asmodee Special Cards
item.comment: More of what you love!

item.name: Dizzy Dizzy Dinosaur
item.comment: Woah, this game could go on forever! That spinning dino can just knock pieces over and over and over. Silly, yes. Fun, no.

item.name: Dominant Species
item.comment: Brilliant. The scientific, evolutionary theme works incredibly well with the boards, bits, and actions. I completely forgot about the pieces and fell into the game. There are so many action choices that it mirrors the chaos of the natural world beautifully. Can't wait to get this and play it with my wife (one of the few games I had to buy immediately after playing once). Only downside is the potential for significant Analysis Paralysis.

item.name: Dominoes
item.comment: Dominoes has never excited me. Not any of the many variants.

item.name: Dragon Racer
item.comment: Card drafting racing game that left me flat. Too many rounds. Unneeded complexity. Felt like a mashup of too many different mechanics. Component quality was poor-cardboard separated after friend's opened the game. Move along.

item.name: Dungeon Run
item.comment: Had a blast playing this with my group. The dungeon romp with monsters and traps is just long enough too be satisfying but not so long as it becomes repetitive. The mechanic of heroes turning on each other to escape the dungeon is positively one of the most fun elements of the game. We simply had a blast. This game does need an expansion to increase the encounter and dungeon tile diversity. This is a keeper for me. Best dungeon crawl game I've played yet!

item.name: Dungeon!
item.comment: Nice light solo dungeon crawl. Plan to keep to play with my kids as they get older. Don't expect I'll pull this out for the fill game group, as there are many, many more interesting group games to play, but solo, and with young kids, this game is a keeper.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
item.comment: Can't make up my mind on this one. Nice miniatures, but becomes so repetitive. Do not enjoy solo very much, though I haven't played through all the scenarios. Yet, when I pulled this out with 2 friends the game became quite fun for that group. The jury is still out.

item.name: Eclipse
item.comment: Very tight Space 4x game. I like how the technology works in the game, and that you're not limited by needing other technologies first. The Ship Upgrades played well, and the combat system of increasing or decreasing dice rolls to get a 6 works well too. Players boards are well organized. I like how the exploration is unknown ahead of time (unlike TI3). Not sure which one I like more at this time.

item.name: Elder Sign
item.comment: Enjoy this very much solo. Basically lots and lots of dice rolling, but it's not like you don't know that when you get the game. Themes is decent, but nothing like the atmospheric world of Arkham Horror. A keeper, but not so much for the group=play, more for the solo aspect.

item.name: Elder Sign: Gates of Arkham
item.comment: Great expansion. Gameplay remains basically the same, yet different mechanics spices up everything. The city locations are great, and add flavor. It's much harder to get items and spells, and makes lots more thematic sense that you get these from different locations you visit. You spent lots more time in Gates that before, which is nice. Wish they had created an out-of-the-box integration with the Museum, as you had to know people would want to mix everything. Still, very pleased.

item.name: Elder Sign: Unseen Forces
item.comment: Takes Elder Sign and improves it. Gives me more characters, more GOOs, more items, and I really like the blessing/curse dice. Highly recommend for owners of Elder Sign. Well done.

item.name: Empire Builder
item.comment: Pick up and delivery, crayon drawing, route finding game. My wife and I enjoy these games. With a few house rules, you can speed up gameplay. We prefer these with 2, as we can play them faster. Never quite the same game twice with the different resources and routes the change with the dealt cards. Definitely some luck involved, but generally good strategy wins out most of the time.

item.name: Enchanted Forest
item.comment: Well designed game with beautiful components. Wife fell instantly in love with this one, as I expected. Move around the board trying to remember where fairy tale objects are hidden, while trying to get to the castle before the king changes the desired object. For a children's game, there's quite a bit of subtle strategy. This will be great for the kids when they get a little older.

item.name: Escape: Illusions
item.comment: Really like the Illusion tiles that disappear. Very neat concept.

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple
item.comment: Fast, quick, tense, easy to explain, neat cooperation with other plays. Just a lot of fun. Not deep, very random, but very fun.

item.name: Eurorails
item.comment: We really enjoy these crayon rail games. We play with quite a few house rules. It's really enjoyable to watch the rail lines grow. There's quite a bit of solitaire action, but when someone does take that final resource, it bites you hard. I enjoy this with two and three players. More than that, though I haven't played with, seems like it would take to long. Highly recommended.

item.name: Fantasy Forest
item.comment: There's more game in this old fantasy game than it looks. Great catch up mechanism. Great simple combat. My wife really enjoys this--got it as a present as she had it when she was a child. Surprising hit.

item.name: Farkle
item.comment: Nothing too interesting here, but far more interesting than Yahtzee. I enjoyed the press your luck option. Erin enjoyed it too. Good game for camping.

item.name: Fireball Island
item.comment: The ultimate game of my youth. Love the board, the marbles, everything. I do recall it lacking some gameplay, but overall it was just too cool. I would like to own it again to play with my kids if I can ever find it reasonable priced.

item.name: Firefly: The Game
item.comment: Feels like the Firefly Universe. Love pick up and deliver games. Like flying in the Alliance and Reaver space sectors. Wish there was more of everything. Doesn't feel as deep as it should, and we'll see how it holds up after repeated plays. Still, very much enjoyed. Game very leaves me wanting to play again after I finish.

item.name: Firefly: The Game – Blue Sun
item.comment: Really enjoy this expansion. Adds a lot of interesting elements to the game.

item.name: Firefly: The Game – Breakin' Atmo
item.comment: Nice to have more variety in the decks. Not sure if it's worth the price. Why didn't they just include them in the base game? Seems like a pure money-grab.

item.name: Firefly: The Game – Pirates & Bounty Hunters
item.comment: Good stuff. Should be more in the box for the price. Don't feel it's that necessary of an expansion. Creates more confrontation which my wife and I don't like.

item.name: FITS
item.comment: Fair game. Good for a Tetris like experience. Wife enjoys it and I enjoy it solitaire. Will keep for a while. Not much in replability, though we might make our own boards. Disappointed by flimsy plastic player backdrops. Do like the plastic pieces. Would never suggest this for more than me and the wife. Would rather play many other 3+ games.

item.name: Fjords
item.comment: Found a great deal on Ebay and didn't pass up this out of print game. Great components. Plays in 30 minutes. I put my copy in a bag and have taken it camping, on trips, to work, lots of places. Only downside is Erin doesn't seem to be that into the game, never requested by her. I thoroughly enjoy it. Update: I do like this, but haven't had great response with other players. Up for trade.

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue
item.comment: Thought I would like this, and finally played a friend's copy. Good tense, fast paced game. Very much like pandemic, with a slightly different feel. If you like cooperative games, you'll like this. Lots of replayability, especially with expansions and addition rules. Recommended.

item.name: Fleet
item.comment: There is a lot going on in this card game. Each card has lots of different uses. Game seems like it is almost over before it starts, but I bet some of the expansions can change that. The short play time is a plus. The fish meeples are awesome.

item.name: Flip Six
item.comment: Surprising card game with more strategy then first appearance. Scalable for time you have. Uses negative numbers which is rare in games and a great math teaching tool for kids. Nice surprise. Don't need to ever buy as the library has it, but I might request it there.

item.name: Fluxx
item.comment: I quite enjoy the original Fluxx. I appreciate the humor and randomness of the goals.

item.name: For Sale
item.comment: Good filler, plays quick. I enjoyed my plays of it so far, but it is not the kind of game that grabs me and demands more plays. Happy to have it, will bring it to game groups for filler games, but probably won't recommend it often. We'll see.

item.name: Forbidden Island
item.comment: Great game to introduce older kids to cooperative gameplay. I can see this being a great gateway into Pandemic and Arkham Horror. There's enough here to keep adult gamers interested for a while, but eventually it seems like it won't replay well. I suppose we'll see. I like the Modular Board, Role Cards, and tension. All aspects leading to deeper games. Worth a look, especially if you have kids.

item.name: Founding Fathers
item.comment: A Euro the has theme fully implemented? Plays relatively quickly? Production vales high? Historical notes all over the game, yet don't invade gameplay? Cards that can be used for multiple choices? This game just blew away my fairly high expectations.

item.name: Freedom: The Underground Railroad
item.comment: A very tough subject matter implemented perfectly and respectful. So nice to see a new theme for a game (I do love scifi/fantasy/exploration, but come on, there's so much material out there for theme!) Love that you can play 1-4. Love the historical detail. This is a tough puzzle of a game. Not for everyone, but absolutely for me.

item.name: Freedom: The Underground Railroad – Promo Cards
item.comment: Love the additional cards.

item.name: Friday
item.comment: Great little solo game. The price is cheap, the components and cards look great. This is the kind of game you play once, lose, and half to play again immediately. I pull this out frequently for 15-30 minutes of fun.

item.name: Frog Juice
item.comment: Neat little card game geared for kids. My wife and I like to play this in the evening when our brains our fried. It's a card collecting game with some basic math. For whatever reason, it works well for me. Would recommend.

item.name: Frontier-6
item.comment: Western themed roll-move-buy property game. Like monopoly but far superior. Properties include cities, cattle ranches, a sheep ranch, farms, farms with oil and gold fields. You can rob banks or rustle cattle. You can chase outlaws or claimjump gold mines. I enjoy playing this a few times a year. This game deserves more attention.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment: If I was fifteen, I would probably enjoy this game a whole lot more. Having said that, I really enjoy this game now. The building component is frenetic, and the traveling through space watching your ship deteriorate is just silly fun. Take the humorous rulebook to heart and just enjoy the game for the fun and not so much for the strategy.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker: The Big Expansion
item.comment: More of the same Galaxy Trucker goodness. Does make the game more complicated as there are more fiddly pieces. If you enjoy the base game, you'll enjoy this.

item.name: The Game of Life
item.comment: This is not a good game. Yet, my wife and I do enjoy this. We create names for our family members and watch things happen to them. Some interest if it doesn't take too long.

item.name: The Game of Life (40th Anniversary Edition)
item.comment: A mind-numbing exercise of a board game. My wife enjoys making up stories of the families, and I enjoy it to some extent, but there are so may other games to play. I enjoyed the original version far more. The updated version is very dumbed down and almost insulting. Still, I'll play when the wife wants to, and eventually if and when the kids do too.

item.name: Game of the States
item.comment: Rated for childhood memories. Loved geography as a kid and the plastic trucks were really cool. Haven't played as an adult and gameplay is probably questionable. One day I'll have to find a copy and try it again.

item.name: A Game of Thrones: The Board Game (Second Edition)
item.comment: Good game. If you like the books or TV series, this game is for you. Evokes its theme perfectly. Tons of intrigue, lots of strategy, enough encounters to keep it interesting, and the wildling attacks keep everyone thinking about something besides just which territory they're going to take over. Not my favorite style of game, but this is a very solid iteration. I see why it ranks so high. Worth checking out.

item.name: Gears of War: The Board Game
item.comment: Repetitive. Bad set-up can make missions a misery fest. Good mechanics, theme, minis, missions; it just doesn't connect with me.

item.name: Global Pursuit
item.comment: I'm a geography buff and simply love this game. I admit, it's distinctly difficult to convince others to play, but I love it. I love the giant die. I love the map pieces. I love the different maps you can make or the giant map. I love the different categories of questions. At heart, this is a trivia game about geography, but it really fills my niche. A keeper for me, but not for most.

item.name: Gloom
item.comment: I love the artwork. I love the morbid, pessimistic, dark world of this game. Yet, my wife and I rarely request this these days. Even picked up and expansion which I've never opened. Maybe the game is too depressing so we just look elsewhere. This may go up for trade soon if we don't start pulling it out again.

item.name: Go Away Monster!
item.comment: My 2 year old daughter has only had this a few days and she's asked to play in over and over. She loves pulling pieces out of the bag and throwing the monsters "away". She doesn't quite understand the full concept, but in a few months to a year she will. Highly recommended for families with small children.

item.name: Gobblet
item.comment: Good condition, mild wear.

item.name: Gother Than Thou
item.comment: Amusing goth card game. A few plays wore out its welcome.

item.name: The Great Fire of London 1666
item.comment: Love how the fire spreads and destroys the houses. Really evokes the theme. No yet sure about longevity or strategy, but I very much like this.

item.name: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone Mystery at Hogwarts Game
Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone The Game
item.comment: All of the Harry Potter Games I've played thus far have been epic fails. Such schlock. Too bad there wasn't so craft with these types of games as the theme and world are so very well crafted.

item.name: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone Trivia Game
item.comment: Meh. Like the Harry Potter world, but there's nothing exciting about this trivia game.

item.name: Heimlich & Co.
item.comment: Great older deduction game. Simply moving pieces around a board to score points, but trying to outside your opponents is a ton of fun, and can be hard work. A keeper.

item.name: Hey, That's My Fish!
item.comment: Great quick game. Perfect for a filler or light evening game. So glad I have this. The cardboard tokens look great, and the plastic penguins are decent. My kids like playing with the pieces. Gameplay has a lot of strategy for the shore game time. Highly recommended.

item.name: Hi Ho! Cherry-O
item.comment: Ugh. No fond memories of this one as a kid. I like cherries too, but this game puts a sour taste in my mouth.

item.name: Hive
item.comment: My favorite abstract at the moment. Great components. Portable. Simple rules--know how each insect moves, in order to trap your opponent's bee. Our go to camping game.

item.name: Hive: The Mosquito
item.comment: Nice small expansion for Hive. You pay a lot for 2 pieces, though. Not worth the price. Got this as a stocking stuffer--would liked it better if the mosquito and the ladybug came together for the same price.

item.name: Hoot Owl Hoot!
item.comment: What an undervalued kids game. Must have. Cooperative, uses color navigation, but as kids get older they begin to see the strategy. Company uses high quality material and environmentally friendly. If you have kids, get this game! One of our favorite kids games.

item.name: How to Host a Murder: Grapes of Frath
item.comment: Silly characters, even worse ending. One of my least favorite murder mysteries.

item.name: How to Host a Murder: The Chicago Caper
item.comment: This is how a murder mystery should be--intriguing, sharp, smart, good characters. Good ending. Highly recommended.

item.name: How to Host a Murder: The Class of '54
item.comment: Another good murder mystery. Enjoyed the theme of this one.

item.name: How to Host a Murder: The Good, The Bad & The Guilty
item.comment: Good murder mystery. On the hokey side. Everyone had fun.

item.name: How to Host a Murder: The Last Train from Paris
Hungry Hungry Hippos
item.comment: My 3 yaer old daughter loves this game. Therefore it ranks higher than it otherwise should. I do admit that there is something strangely appealing to chomping marbles with hippo shaped devices..

item.name: I Spy Eagle Eye
item.comment: A search and find games for kids. Nothing exciting. However, this is one kids of 3+ can play and enjoy. And they can beat the parents, which is neat. For that reason, i will hold on to this until my kids are grown.

item.name: In a Pickle
item.comment: A game of comparisons: what's greater than this? What's hotter than that? What's smellier than the other? Another teaching tool game that could be good for kids, but for the average gamer, this has little fun value. This won some awards and I don't get it.

item.name: Industrial Waste
item.comment: Only looked at this once. Seemed to business oriented to me. Rated fairly highly on BGG, but didn't strike any interest for me or my wife.

item.name: Infection: Humanity's Last Gasp
item.comment: Nice shorter solo game. A puzzle. Will keep and play every so often when need a 30 min solo game. Theme is implemented very well. Nothing astonishing, but for those who like solo games, this one should be tried.

item.name: Ingenious: Travel Edition
item.comment: Wife really enjoyed this. I don't typically enjoy abstracts, but this one hit a sweet spot--not too long, enough interesting decisions, but not too many. The travel edition is the perfect size.

item.name: Inner Circle
item.comment: Thrift Store Find. Had this as a kid, played solo, but never with anyone. Some interest every once in a while. The boards do rotate so its never exactly the same game, but this seems like it will lose its appeal after a few plays. Not there yet though.

item.name: Inside
item.comment: Interesting abstract game or stacking cubes. Once you've played it a few times, I then fail to see the interest. It's the same game, with subtle strategy, true, every time. The wooden pieces look great, though. Great coffee table game if you like this style. Traded mine away. Cathedral is my go to wooden abstract game right now.

item.name: Jacks
item.comment: A kids dexterity game. Can be amusing every so often.

item.name: Jenga
item.comment: A basic dexterity game. Fun if your 10, otherwise I'd rather drop the blocks one by one on my toes than actually play any more games of this.

item.name: Ker Plunk
item.comment: As a kid, twenty-five years ago, best memory was when I beat my brother. He then threw the marbles at me from only two feet away. Several marbles hit me in the head at high speed. I fell over backwards and had several large welts. We are on better terms now. No real desire to revisit this game today.

item.name: Key Largo
item.comment: Good game. Easy game play. Straight forward and well designed. Everything is very clear. Quick to learn. Theme, board, gameplay, and components all complement each other nicely. Good family gateway game. Enough strategy to keep gamers interested, yet simple enough that anyone can learn it quickly and have a good time. Highly recommended.

item.name: Kings of Air and Steam
item.comment: Pick up and deliver game. I enjoy the planning for the turn and then the unveiling. Good Game. Can be very tense as other teams fly around, wondering if the goods you want will still be there. Analysis Paralysis can make it take too long.

item.name: Labyrinth
item.comment: A surprising amount of strategy for this old-time children's game. Wife likes it, and I enjoy it. Look forward to teaching it to my kids. Good game.

item.name: The Ladybug Game
item.comment: Rated for a children's game. There's a short story that comes with the game. You move along the path through the different elements of the game. You collect aphids and passes to keep moving. The addition and subtraction in the game is great for kids. Recommended for families for young kids. Enjoy it for what it is suppose to be, that's all. Biggest gripe is why don't kid's games have bigger draw decks? This isn't a long game. Why should we have to shuffle twice for this short game. 30 cards? That's all?

item.name: Lancaster
item.comment: A worker placement game (knights) with different value for the knights, which causes deeper strategy and more player interaction. Still try to accumulate victory points through various methods, but there are many different ways. I would like to explore this game further.

item.name: Lanterns: The Harvest Festival
item.comment: Neat tile laying and set collection game. Receiving cards on other players' turn is a great way to keep everyone interested in the game. Don't need to own this game, but happy to play it.

item.name: Last Night on Earth: The Zombie Game
item.comment: I was surprised I did not like this game. Perhaps the group simply wasn't into the mood, but it was boring. Other players simply ran across the board, then back, the across again running away from zombies. The cooperation and teamwork were significantly lacking and this resulted in a resounding defeat for the human players. This may say more for the day and the group of players, but for normally loving coop games, this one fell flat for me. Basically you can search for items in different buildings, which come up at random from the deck, move, or try to fight a zombie. There's not actually a lot to do in this game. In addition the characters aren't interesting and there aren't very many. Arkham Horror and Pandemic put this coop to shame.

item.name: Last Word
item.comment: Take or leave this game. Eventually gave away. Had some moments of fun, but there are many, many other games I'd rather play.

item.name: Legendary Encounters: An Alien Deck Building Game
Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
item.comment: Theme doesn't interest me. The box is just a bunch of cards. I felt like I was just pushing paper around for no real point. The characters could have been anything. I didn't feel like I was doing anything superhero related. I can see how people like it, but not for me. Did enjoy it more after a fun game with friends, but not enough to raise my rating.

item.name: Legends of Andor
item.comment: Very interesting fantasy monster slaying game. Different than most--much more of a puzzle--kill too many monsters, and you run out of time. It's too bad that Fantasy Flight is not issuing expansions as there are only a few scenarios in the base game, although it can be replayed. Good game, but not graet.

item.name: LEGO Pirates Treasure Game
item.comment: There's actually an interesting game here. A really nice memory aspect--key colors. A neat 3-D board atmosphere--one complaint is that kids can look under the hanging board to see the keys dangling below, but as my wife found out by reading the directions thoroughly (who knew?), you're supposed to place the bottom of the box under the board for additional support, and this hides the keys. Clever! Whomever owned our copy previously tricked out the cardboard coins with nifty, shiny doubloons. This is still a "Spin, move, and land on necessary spaces" game, so the track around the board is kind of silly. Also, this is a game where the components won't last long--one nefarious person and the 3-D board will be squashed. I'll keep this longer for further evaluation. Tess loved the spinner and also got to practice counting her coins. One... Two... Three...

item.name: Lewis & Clark
item.comment: This is a great game, but I can't get it too the table yet. It's a brainburner.

item.name: Livingstone
item.comment: Great looking game. Simple gameplay, beautiful components. I like the donation boxes, and that element adds a nice tension. Quick,light game that has interesting use of dice, enough choices to be interesting. Really like how quick this plays.

item.name: Loot
item.comment: Another game that rates much higher than my experience. Perhaps it is because I only played it 2-player or 3-player. Did not work. Became an exercise, not a game.

item.name: Lost Cities
item.comment: I enjoyed this game a few times, but it just seems so monotonous and luck driven. Plus you could play this with a standard deck of cards and save yourself the money. The components looked nice, but it was basically a math exercise in disguise. Don't know why this game ranks so high. Traded mine away.
item.conditiontext: Light wear on cards. Box, directions, and board in good condition. Played 34 times over 8 years, most in the first two years (2004, 2005)

item.name: Lost Treasure
item.comment: Fond memories of this one as a kid. Diving for treasure was always intense. Curious to try this one again now to see if it is as fun as I remember. I don't think I ever played this with anyone but myself.

item.name: Lost Valley
item.comment: I really want to like this game, but after a few plays to learn the system, I've never really wanted to pull it back out. I'll have to try it and see more, though.

item.name: Lotto
item.comment: While there is no strategy in this game, it is good for kids. Tess really enjoys flipping over face down tiles and matching the objects. I'll gladly play this with the kids while they are young. All 4 of us are able to play this one, though little Nigel (1.5) loses interest.

item.name: Love Letter
item.comment: Good game. Citadels light. My wife and I enjoyed our first game (borrowed a friend's copy). Nice light, quick game with a dash of psychological strategy. Recommended, but I don't need to rush out and buy my own copy.

item.name: Love Letter: Batman
item.comment: Another theme for Love Letter? Meh. Hate the artwork. Move along.

item.name: Luna
item.comment: This is one of the few games I didn't understand by just reading the directions. It took about three rounds before it really started making sense. Once the different actions began to make sense, the game play really began to fascinate me. This is a highly under-rated, probably because of the theme, which I find to be a big plus. This will get many more plays (as expected!) Follow up many months later-yet to pull it out again. Hmmm... Finally pulled it out again, stiff learning curve still, but the variations of possible choices have bumped this to a 9 from a 7. Definite keeper.

item.name: Mad Gab
item.comment: So many other party games I'd rather play. Wife enjoys it, so will humor her from time to time. I will never request it. Boring.

item.name: The Mad Magazine Game
item.comment: Thrift store find for a few dollars. Loved this game as a kid. As an adult, it loses some of its luster. Be the first to lose all your money. Still, wife and I enjoyed it when we pulled it out late one night after the kids were asleep. Good if you play for fun and not to win. Completely silly.

item.name: Mage Knight Board Game
item.comment: This is a good game. The components are fantastic. I find the exploration of the world and fighting of monsters fun. I enjoy the reputation track. However, I cannot stand the deckbuilding aspect of the game. Every game felt the same. Each character felt the same. Yes you get a few different cards and skills over the course of the game, but all the characters basically felt the same. Plus, I despise the movement in the game. What? I didn't draw any movement cards? I can't move unless I discard most of my cards which I will need in order to find or recruit? Incredibly frustrating. Not for me.

item.name: Magic: The Gathering
item.comment: Created the deck-building craze. Enjoyed while in high school. No longer enjoy the money-sink that these types of games cause. Just rather play so many other things. Still, there were some good games with friends in its past.

item.name: Make 'n' Break CHALLENGE
item.comment: Surprisingly Fun Dexterity Game. My wife and I played this at a Library Game Day and she played many games. The tongues were amusing to place the shapes. Would be better with more shapes and construction possibilities. Still, I see us playing that some more when we go to the library.

item.name: Mancala
item.comment: Mancala holds great emotional connections for me, as my wife and I played it when we were first getting together. I enjoy this one more than most abstracts. Probably won't suggest it, but will certainly play if requested.

item.name: Mansions of Madness
item.comment: This is a good thematic game. It's more about the story and atmosphere than winning or losing. Turn down the lights, light some candles, put on some dark music, and you've got an enjoyable evening. Nice components and minis. Love the way the board changes for each scenario. Lots of Fiddly Rules (this is FFG) which I can see annoying many people. Takes a long time to set-up and to play, which means my wife and I won't play much with little kids. Now my group has interest in it, and we're playing it more, and I like it even better. Definitely a keeper.

item.name: Mansions of Madness: Call of the Wild
item.comment: This expansion really tried to do some new things, with the allies, and I enjoy that and all the new scenarios. Good expansion.

item.name: Mansions of Madness: Forbidden Alchemy
item.comment: Wish this expansion had been bigger. The Alchemy puzzle and cards are great, and I wish there were more scenarios that used the. More investigators and monsters are great. Stories are good. Since they fixed the issues they had when it was first released, this is a good, though not great, expansion.

item.name: Mansions of Madness: House of Fears
item.comment: This scenario was really enjoyable. It had some unique twists to the typical exploring the house scenario. Will definitely play again.

item.name: Mansions of Madness: The Silver Tablet
item.comment: This scenario didn't work out that well, but I've only played it once.

item.name: Marbles
item.comment: Infinite number of different games one can play with marbles. Enjoyed sporadically as a kid. Don't play anymore today. Maybe with the kids when older.

item.name: Martian Fluxx
item.comment: More Fluxx, but the silly theme fits the gameplay well. I really enjoy this version.

item.name: Max
item.comment: Game for very young kids. They enjoy it and understand it. Try to get your animals to safety for Max, the Cat, eats them. Some nice life lessons here. Rated for playing with my kids. Good, but not great, game for kids.

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment: Nice surprise of the game. Even my wife like it, and its a wargame! Granted, it's simplified from most wargames, but the flavor is definitely the same. Nice components, great hex terrain system, nice dice, nice miniatures. I enjoyed the command card orders, though can see why some would not like this technique. Definitely some luck in this game, which I don't mind, but also a lot of strategy. 16 Scenarios is the first gamebox is great! (5 in Mansions? Pathetic).

item.name: Mice and Mystics
item.comment: Great Story. Gamplay is roll a die. Some tactical strategy, but not much. Great for younger players or families. Has not held any group's interest after one play. Listened to an interview where the win ratio was planned as 70%. That sure hasn't been my experience-more like 25%. Good game, just not great.

item.name: Mice and Mystics: Needle Rapier
item.comment: Two additional cards. Nothing fancy.

item.name: Mice and Mystics: Tattered Threads of Reason
item.comment: A new equipment card. Nothing fancy.

item.name: Michiganopoly
item.comment: Monopoly with a University of Michigan feeling. Two things I really don't care about anymore. Blah.

item.name: Midnight Party
item.comment: Game for older kids. Try to hide from the ghost or he sends you to the cellar. Good strategy and math game. My wife really enjoys it. There's just enough to keep adult's interest, and I can see how kids love the ghost aspect. Nice board. My kids are still too young too play this though. Will reevaluate in a few years.

item.name: Mistfall
item.comment: This is a game I will only play solo. You have to know all your cards in order to survive the scenario. A lot of care was put into developing the character and the decks. I wish that much attention was put into the rulebook--it's well laid out, yet the translation is not quite right and elements are missing for ease of use. I look forward to immersing myself, but feel know need to immerse others.

item.name: Monopoly
item.comment: Ugh. Hyper Competetive. Large doses of random chance? Once you discover BGG, there's little hope of this game seeing the table again, at least by your own choice.

item.name: Monopoly: National Parks Edition
item.comment: Monopoly with a National Parks theme. This seems highly illogical--National Parks are supposed to be preserved, not exploited, traded, developed, and sold. I can't play this again.

item.name: Monopoly: Star Wars Limited Collector's Edition
item.comment: Monopoly with Star Wars? Who cares?

item.name: Monty Python Fluxx
item.comment: My least favorite fluxx version thus far. After a few plays it capture everything annoying about Monty Python and nothing that was good.

item.name: Morels
item.comment: Great 30 minute card game. Just enough strategy to keep it interesting. Theme is integrated perfectly. Both my wife and my mom enjoy it. Highly exceeded my expectations.

item.name: Mouse Trap
item.comment: I did so love this game as a kid. All the working parts coming together are a great lessen in engineering. Yes, this is a roll and move game, but who really cares about the gameplay of mousetrap? Look forward to playing with my kids.

item.name: Mush! Mush!: Snow Tails 2
item.comment: Neat, quick racing game. Concept of sled dogs and how the mechanics deal with this theme are well-done. Trees are a nice effect. Not sure about replability, but I enjoyed my play of this game.

item.name: Nature Fluxx
item.comment: Not one of my favorite fluxxes, though I often think it should be. I don't mind playing it.

item.name: Obstacles
item.comment: Rated for kids. My 5 year old daughter got this for her birthday from her grandparents. She requests it almost every day since. It is not really a game, more a discussion, as players choose an object that will help them get past an obstacle, and get closer to home. Very imaginative. My three year old plays too. Biggest negative is it just doesn't come with enough cards. More of everything is needed.

item.name: On Assignment with National Geographic
item.comment:
I love geography based games, but this one's gameplay falls flat. It doesn't quite work or make sense. This pictures on the cards are quite nice, though.
11/24/13 Just played this again with Erin, and we both enjoyed the concept, and with a house rule or two this is a good geography game (no wildcards, 2 possible photo card draw piles instead of 1. Not something for gamers, but great for families.

item.name: Once Upon a Time: The Storytelling Card Game
item.comment: Not enough game for me. I appreciate the storytelling aspect of this, and the creation of imagination, but when my wife and I played we would break down into arguing over who could interrupt whom. Not enough fun. Traded away.

item.name: Onirim (second edition)
item.comment: This is a good game, but it's just too abstract. Match colors and shuffle cards repeatedly. I was hoping for more.

item.name: Operation
item.comment: One of the original dexterity games for kids. I'd play this with my own kids but would never recommend it.

item.name: Ora et Labora
item.comment: Complex game with almost too much happening. High learning curve to play with the plethora of resources, resource production, and land management. Plus a ton of match at the end. Interesting, but fell flat for me. Not one I need to own.

item.name: Orient Express
item.comment:
[b]The Game[/b] Move around the Orient Express train. Suspects and crew all move around too. At certain locations, send a telegram for more clues. Lock clues away with bribes. Try to deduce the murderer before the train reaches Varna. Lots of logic puzzles to deduce.
[b]Opinion[/b]: This is one of the best mystery deduction games I've played. The train and passenger movement is a really great touch. If you like deduction games, this is for you. Issues: Deduction Sheet is confusing to use, and my wife didn't like it. Some editions are much nicer than others. Overall: Great.

item.name: Outburst: Travel Edition
item.comment: I always enjoyed Outburst. This was one large group game that I'd request, though few others would. Fond memories, but no need to reacquire from my youth.

item.name: Outdoor Survival
item.comment: Basic survival simulation game. Only play solo, and I find it quite enjoyable. A nice, quick, easy evening game. It's something a little different. Glad I got this is a Math Trade.

item.name: Oz Fluxx
item.comment: Yet another Fluxx. My wife and brother and law simply love fluxx and all the themes. I don't mind them, but no longer seek them out. The Oz theme is another that works well for the Fluxx world. I'll say this: they choose good themes and blend them pretty well into their mechanics.

item.name: Pachisi
item.comment: For an abstract game, I do enjoy this. It's simplicity is endearing. Good for snowy days and cups of cocoa. I'd play when suggested, but probably won't suggest it myself.

item.name: Pack the Pack
item.comment: Fun, quick, pattern geometry game with a fantasy theme. Nothing too deep here, but a neat take on a tetris-pattern like game.

item.name: Palazzo
item.comment: What a delightful discovery. Picked this up in an auction for cheap to combine shipping. My wife and I have been pleasantly surprised playing this. The auction mechanism works really well for 2-players. Building your palazzos keeps my interest, trying to juggling building up more different palazzos or focusing on a few and getting as much value as you can. Great game, especially about once a month.

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: Great solo or coop game that simulates diseases spreading across the globe. Significant random chance, but I feel it plays very true to life.

item.name: Pandemic: On the Brink
item.comment: Makes Pandemic that much better. Instead of one game, you get several different variants. You can even play as a bio-terrorist, trying to destroy the world as the other players try to thwart you. This expansion takes a good game and makes it great.

item.name: Pastiche
item.comment: Color collection game to make works of great art. Superb theme. Good gameplay, but pretty basic. Get color cards based on matching tiles at the start of your turn. Can play in about an hour which is the perfect length for a game of this magnitude.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Base Set
item.comment: The structure of the game, with its hand size being your life, and the way your deck changes over the course of the campaign is a neat mechanic. But being just a card game, it feels like you're doing the same thing over and over again. Read a card, role a die, without any variation. Too much set-up time for not enough theme. The flavor text is well written though.

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Skull & Shackles – Base Set
Pay Day
item.comment: Money Collection game from my youth. It simulates a month of running a household--get mail, pay bills, try to make money. You can play any number of rounds from 1 month to 1 year (12). It this manner, the timeframe is scalable which I really like. If only the spaces on the board could change with each month, this would be more enjoyable. I understand how this wouldn't appeal to many gamers, but I think this is great at introducing kids to money management. We'll see if my kids enjoy it in a few years.

item.name: PDQ: The Pretty Darn Quick Word Game
item.comment: For a quick word game, this one is pretty fun. Don't play it super regularly, but enjoy it when I do. Lots of variants. Can play with cards or tiles from any wordgame.

item.name: Pente
item.comment: A solid game, I've just lost much interest in abstracts. Found for a few bucks at a comic book store. I appreciate the design and how it came to exist. The version I have has a ridiculously huge box to accommodate a non-folding board. Big waste of space. Will likely trade or send to the thrift store in the near future.

item.name: Perfection
item.comment: I like solo games, but this is just an exercise in dexterity before the pop. No replayability.

item.name: Perry Rhodan: The Cosmic League
item.comment: Nicely designed 2-player only game. Nice thematic elements with movement costs differing depending on which way one is traveling through the system. Card play creates enough variability between games. The double-sided resource cards are a neat mechanic for a game "time" element as well as restocking of resources on the worlds. Recommended Fully.

item.name: Phase 10
item.comment: My wife really enjoys this game from her childhood. For me, it's too long for what it is. I appreciate the phase dynamics, but standard card collecting games don't interest me as much these days. I'm happy to play with Erin when requested, but I'll never suggest this.

item.name: Philanthropist: A Window on the World of Painting
