item.comment: Art History Trivia game. Gameplay is trivia-boring, and very difficult if you're not an art history buff, but the painting representations are fantastic.

item.name: Pick & Pack
item.comment: Received this game in a math trade. I knew the theme would appeal (pun intended) to my wife, and I finally pulled it out to play the week of Thanksgiving. How thematic! There's more here then the game suggests at first glance. A surprising amount of strategy and long term thought can be put into every turn. The special tiles add an additional strategic element. Only downside is there can be some Analysis Paralysis during each player's turn. A good family and 2-player game. A keeper. Strongly recommended.

item.name: Pick Up Sticks
item.comment: One of the first dexterity games kids play. Amusing with kids. Otherwise, yawn.

item.name: Pictionary
item.comment: There are better party games out there. Yet this has been around for a long time for good reason. I still enjoy it.

item.name: Po-Ke-No
item.comment: Blah. Nothing of interest here.

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment: Played once and greatly enjoyed the mechanics. There's some auction, resource management, and plenty of strategy. I like the theme, it works well with the gameplay. Only downside is there's plenty of opportunity for Analysis Paralysis. This is Ticket to Ride for Grown-Ups.

item.name: Power Grid deluxe: Europe/North America
item.comment: Not a fan of this version. While the box art of the original edition is boring, the cartoony, childish version in this edition doesn't sit well with me. Some of the minor changes annoy me--the plastic money is awful. While paper money gets a bad wrap, it sure was better than this dreadful plastic crud. Gameplay is mostly the same as the original, and so I enjoyed my play of this, but I sure don't need this version, and will enjoy the original very much, thank you.

item.name: Power Grid: Russia & Japan
item.comment: Same great game. New Maps and rule variants keeps it fresh. Huge fan.

item.name: Power Grid: The Robots
item.comment: Only used once. Seemed to be just as much work to use a robot as to play a character yourself. Will try again, but it didn't work for me on the first play.

item.name: The Princes of Florence
item.comment: It took a while for this one to hit the table, but when it finally did, it was every bit of geeky fun I assumed it would be. This has a little of everything, auction, puzzle/board management, money/prestige point (victory point) management, plenty of strategy. This one is an absolute geeky keeper, but not one I would introduce to new gamers right away. When introduced to the wife, she took to it immediately. Won't hit the table often due to length and complexity, but a really gem of a game.

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment: Though this gets high reviews, and I do appreciate the game, it started to feel very predictable and very similar play after play. There were so many other games I'd rather play, that I traded this away. I understand why many receive it well, but not for me.

item.name: Quarriors!
item.comment: Strange dice-building and rolling game. Silly, random, quick (mostly), but lots of fun with the right people. Not one I need to own, but one I would play with frequently with the right group.

item.name: Quarriors! Rise of the Demons
item.comment: Nice expansion to Quarriors.

item.name: Queen's Architect
item.comment: Enjoyed this game. I liked the board and moving around to maximize your wheel. A lot going on. Lost badly my first play. Would definitely play again.

item.name: Quiddler
item.comment: My mom loves word games and requests this frequently. My wife requests this as well to a lesser extent. You receive letters, make words, add up the score, and repeat. As word games go, and I generally like them, this one gets boring for me. I'll play it when my mom or wife suggest it, but I doubt I'll suggest it myself. One bonus of this game is the cards can also be used to play PDQ, a Gamewright game.

item.name: Quoridor
item.comment: Disappointed with the edition I purchased. Wooden components were the least refined I'd ever seen. Plus, what I thought would be a good 2-player game with my wife, turned into a real snooze fest. The strategy didn't work for either my wife or me. Traded away.
item.conditiontext: Light Box wear. Good condition. Complete "fences" and pawns.

item.name: Qwirkle
item.comment: Glad to finally play this. It was about what I expected, making color and shape patterns. It's still an abstract, and I'm not certain why this one has done so well while others fade. My wife enjoyed the play more than i did. I would play this again, but I don't need to own it.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment: Good game. Interesting card playing mechanics. I like civilization building games, but this is still just a card game. Lots of small details to keep track of. I'd play this again, but don't think I need to own it.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy: The Gathering Storm
item.comment: Played a couple of times solo. I enjoy the added cards and the solobot. Good, not great, for me.

item.name: Rail Baron
item.comment: I've always liked train games, geography games, and also games based in solid historical accuracy. The train routes have been thoroughly thought out. One of the few games one of my brothers will play with me (because he's a train buff). Still, this is a long game, that easily becomes monotonous--moving, paying, buying rail lines. I do love the payoff chart and the end of game chance. Not for everyone, but a keeper for me.

item.name: Red November
item.comment: Good, silly fun,. I really enjoy the theme of this game as the gnomes run from room to room trying to stay alive. I also really enjoy the time and turn order mechanism, which means the player further behind always takes the next move. Yes, there's a fair bit of randomness due to the event cards, but that's what makes the game fun in my opinion--trying to manage the chance and randomness. There are times when certain victory is snatched away at the last minute or when you amazingly survive against seemingly impossible odds. This is also any easy game to play solo, which I do with some frequency. Erin enjoyed this play even more than her first (less tired), and we both had a lot of fun. I love this game!

item.name: Release!
item.comment: This game made me feel like I was inside I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream. It was 5 rounds of Phase 10 with negative point values and random objectives every round. I was ready to be done after 1 round. Not my kind of game.

item.name: The Resistance
item.comment: Good quick psychological game that plays well with large groups. Will play in a game group, but probably don't need to own.

item.name: Return of the Heroes
item.comment:
This is a well designed game. There is a lot going on, but the overall structure is straight forward, and easy to grasp after a play through. Print out some of the simple rules summations, as the original English rules, written by native German speakers, while entertaining, is difficult to reference. I can see this game really appealing to 10-15 year olds as they start to venture into deeper games.
Nice basic character development game.
Don't know how well it will hold for repeated plays.
Interested in solo versions, but think it will feel like the same thing after a few games. We'll see.

item.name: Rex: Final Days of an Empire
Richard Scarry's Busytown: Busy, Busy Airport Game
item.comment: Wow, what a great kid game. Clever use of the box. Neat airplanes which kids get to load, and you fly them around the room based on where you place the location cards. A great first pick up and deliver game. It also comes with a dice tower for kids disguised as airport control tower. This is an absolutely awesome kids game. Highly recommend it. My 3 year old daughter already loves it.

item.name: Richard Scarry's Busytown: Eye found it! Game
item.comment: Love the six foot board. It's beautiful and full of Busytown madness! The game at it's heart is a spin and move, and that lowers it. It is cooperative--everyone is trying to reach Picnic Island before the pigs eat all of lunch, and it is not easy. There's a 1 in 4 chance that the pigs will eat every turn. The search cards are well done, where every player searches for items on the board and marks them with magnifying glasses. Then you all move based on the number you found in the time allotted. Replability will suffer once the kids no where everything is located. The kids heard the rules from their mom, then taught me in the evening. For that reason alone, this is a great younger kid game.

item.name: Ricochet Robots
item.comment: Thought I would like the puzzle aspect and would get some good solo plays out of it, but there's not enough to the game. I enjoy the chunky robot pawns. Neat idea, but don't see myself pulling out much solo or with others.

item.name: Risk
item.comment:
Though I haven't played this in years and probably won't play it again until the kids are of the right age, this is a classic. It's a great introductory strategy and chance game.
My wife and I once played almost an entire game of Risk by making each battle be a game of Fluxx; whoever won the card game won the battle. Six months later, my wife conceeded as my Fluxx minions started to overwhelm her Icelandic army. This game was before I tracked our plays, and it's too bad because we played about 250 games of Fluxx during this extended game of Risk.

item.name: Risk 2210 A.D.
item.comment: Great update to the Risk game genre. Something new when it came out, though now there are many other versions. Gladly play a few times a year. I enjoy the commanders, command cards, and five year timespan. Just enough different from Risk to be fresh, but not so different that it's a different game entirely. Roll those dice!

item.name: Risk 2210 A.D. Frontline: Season One – Mars
Risk: The Lord of the Rings
Risk: The Lord of the Rings Trilogy Edition
River Dragons
item.comment: We had a lot of laughs with this game, not because it is a humorous game, but because the dang bridges and people kept falling over, and over, and over. Kevin was saying this game wasn't selling, and I'm not surprised, since it's so tip-over prone. Basically a race across bridges. Okay game. Had a fun play, but don't see myself playing it again.

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventure on the Cursed Island – Beast Cards
Robinson Crusoe: Adventure on the Cursed Island – Trait Cards I
item.comment: These promos don't excite me. They seem overly harsh. Haven't used them yet.

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventure on the Cursed Island – Voyage of the Beagle (Vol. 1)
item.comment:
This is an absolutely fantastic expansion. A campaign style adventure based on Darwin's Voyageurs aboard the Beagle, which led to the theory of evolution, is truly an inspired design. Love the new cards, crewmates, missionary character, etc.
The rulebook and scenario sheets are very good, complex, but very good. I hated the base games rulebook, and I try not to complain about rulebooks.
Can't wait to play more.

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
item.comment: This is a really well designed game. It's addicting. So much going on. Yes, their is a fair amount of luck with dice rolls and card flips, but as with many games, its all about luck management. I really feel like I'm on the island struggling to survive. Plays great solo. Only reason it is not a 10 is because the rulebook is horrible--a perfect example of how NOT to write a rulebook. You can't find anything quickly, no index, poor headings, and constant "important" headings which are meaningless and don't help you find the important info you are looking for. It does take time to learn, but once you do, it is absolutely worth it.

item.name: Rummikub
item.comment: Never had any interest in playing.

item.name: Russian Rails
item.comment: Got this in a Math Trade, and the wife and I pulled it out almost immediately. We just love these games 2-players. The new routes, cities, and goods, gives us more of what we love.

item.name: Saboteur
item.comment: Who is the saboteur? Lots of good deduction in this game. Fun. Analysis Paralysis can hamper the game. Seems to go on for too long.

item.name: Samurai Sword
item.comment: Decent game, but my gosh it takes far too long. Because you can steal back honor from each other, the game could never end. That's awful! The time on this listing says 30 miuntes! Yeah, right! It took nearly 2 hours. Anaylsis Paralysis just extends the game as well.

item.name: Sanitarium
item.comment:
This was my opinion 1/22/12. Great game! This was my first kickstarter-backed game that I've received. It was definitely worth the wait! I backed this game because I love sanitarium themed games, and I would have been happy enough with the theme and artwork even if the gameplay was lacking. But it played great! The multiple scenarios create high replayability, and I think this game will scale very well with more players. There was definite tension as the shadows moved around the board, and as the game progressed, they became harder and harder to escape and more and more hallucinations occurred.
As of 5/27/13, this game has not weathered time well. Repeated plays have been snooze-fests, and I'd always rather play something else with my game group then Sanitarium. Even solo, I always reach for something else. While I still love the artwork, and plan to keep this small-box game, it won't see many plays.

item.name: Sator Arepo Tenet Opera Rotas
item.comment: I love the strange theme and production value in this game. There's something super creepy about all the Latin. I find the moving bridges and books a very cool and different gameplay. Not really for everyone, but high on my list of keepers. My sister-in-law, a connoisseur or Latin, needs to play this one! Two downsides: 1) The provided player aid is indecipherable to new players and 2) significant analysis paralysis potential.

item.name: Scarab Lords
item.comment: I picked this game up in a Math Trade. It falls in the same category as Gates of Loyang in the sense that I don't think I should like it as much as I do. Play time is quick and there's enough strategy to be interesting. It feels similar to Lost Cities, which I traded away, but more fun. Not one I'll pull out frequently, but a keeper for now. Erin likes it to. The box is much bigger than it needs to be. This could be a very portable game.

item.name: Scattergories
item.comment: Use to love this as a kid and I enjoy word games. Now, I'd rather play many other things. Wife never suggests it either.

item.name: Scene It? Movie
item.comment: More cumbersome than the Second Edition, which I prefer. The box is bigger and the board doesn't look as nice. Still, the gameplay is quick and the variety of question types keeps the game interesting.

item.name: Scene It? Movie Second Edition
item.comment: One of my favorite trivia games. The game play is quick and there's a variety of different types of questions. My wife and I each do better at certain categories. We like to play this in bed.

item.name: Scene It? TV
item.comment: Least favorite of all Scene It Versions.

item.name: Scotland Yard
item.comment: As a kid, this was the first truly different gameplay mechanic that I learned. Using the tokens to move around the city of London fascinated me, and I love the map of London. I have a copy of this at my parents place, and picked up one for my wife and me, but over the last few years, this never hit the table much, so I decided to trade my copy (a new Ravensburger edition) and keep the older, more classic version at my parent's house. Still have a lot of nostalgic love for this game, and I'll probably always keep a version around. Great game to introduce to new gamers. Easy to learn and a nice amount of strategy.

item.name: Scrabble
item.comment: My mom played scrabble relentless when I was little, often playing solo. She still plays solo today (too bad I can't get her into so many other games...). We're both so good that my wife won't play with me (I don't blame her). However, my mom claims I always beat her (not true as I have the game statistics to prove it), so she has started to complain about everything, and games have become less fun over the years. I still always play this with her, though. This is classic that deserves its accolades.

item.name: Scrabble: The National Parks Edition
item.comment: I love the National Parks and work for them, but I really despise the National Park board games. In the case of Scrabble, tack on a few bonus points for special park-related words, and you've got a new Scrabble version. I'll stick with the original, thanks.

item.name: The Secret Door
item.comment: Wow, what a great memory game for kids! I really enjoyed this play. The time element adds a sense of tension for the adults. Tess really got into turning over the hidden items. She doesn't yet quite know how to play, but she will soon. I'll happily play this for the foreseeable future.

item.name: Secrets of the Lost Tomb
item.comment: Wow. Really enjoyed this play through. Had a super busy week and work, and just wanted to play this when I got home. It fills a similar niche like [thing=15987]Arkham Horror[/thing]--random stories happen to your chracters and you have find a way to survive--except toss in an exploration dungeon crawl on three levels that is always changing. This will not be for everyone, but like Arkham Horror, this sure is for me. At least after 1 solid play. The combat is a little cumbersome--adding and subtracting different numbers for critical hits and defense, but it does work, and once I've played a few times, I don't think it will hinder gameplay much, merely slow it down a little (I very much appreciate the simple combat in Arkham Horror). Love the Health and Audacity dials (why don't more games use these dials!), and the courage track is a really neat invention with positive and negative affects--I do worry that the cardboard ARM Overlay won't last long with all the Courage Peg Action. Greatly disappointed with the miniatures--glad I didn't fork over additional money for additional minis. Rules and basic editing could have used several more revisions (as with many Kickstarter games). Overall, greatly enjoy.

item.name: Secrets of the Lost Tomb: Ancient Myths and Legends
item.comment: More stuff. Like the base game. Story missions are fun, but tons of little things detract from the overall experience.

item.name: Secrets of the Lost Tomb: The Great Apocalypse
item.comment: More stuff. Like the base game. Story missions are fun, but tons of little things detract from the overall experience.

item.name: Sequence
item.comment: Sequence is not high on my list of games to play, but it's a quick game we can play after work. I'll play every so often, but there are many other games I'd rather play. Good for when your brain power is low, though.

item.name: Sequence Dice
item.comment: A random card game now with dice? Not for me. Ugh.

item.name: Sequence for Kids
item.comment: Yawn. This game can go on forever. Really don't enjoy it. But the kids like to identify the animals. Okay, I'll play. Thrift find. Would not buy.

item.name: SET
item.comment: Pattern recognition gone crazy, yet I still enjoy this. Another game that I first learned as a kid, even with friends, and my wife enjoys it now. Probably won't request it too often, but I'll always play when she requests it. Great for kids learning colors, shapes, and patterns. Good basic game that plays quick.

item.name: Shadows of Brimstone: Caverns of Cynder Expansion
item.comment: Good stuff in the box. Just way not enough. One new villain; that's all you get. Just one. The new world, map tiles, cards, are all great, but I'm definitely disappointed there wasn't more in this expansion. There's so much potential with this game and world, but it just under delivers. I can't believe they included Poker chips to track things like Gold an XP in an expansion and not in the original game, not to mention generic tokens don't really help to keep track of these things. Just needed more development.

item.name: Shadows of Brimstone: City of the Ancients
item.comment:
Man oh man this game has a lot I like. Great minis. Changeable maps. Leveling up characters. Recouping in town. Other worlds.
But...
This game is stuck in the middle of what it wants to be. It comes with tons of cardboard pieces, yet you need pencil and paper to track character changes and basic gold and XP. Why couldn't they create a character card with spinning dials to track changes?
I like this game, will definitely keep playing, but I'm struggling with "what could have been"
Discovering the Hexcrawl Campaign has made me really excited to keep playing this.

item.name: Shadows of Brimstone: Doorways into Darkness
item.comment: Doorways are very cool. Pure component wonderfulness. Few extra cards tossed in for different decks is a nice touch. Just wish there was more of everything. Stuff in expansions feels like they're being very chintzy. Good stuff, but overall disappointed.

item.name: Shadows of Brimstone: Swamps of Death
item.comment: More Shadows of Brimstone goodness. More of the same stuff. More characters and monsters and scenarios. Gameplay still has all the same flaws.

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
item.comment: While the game is based on matching poker hands as "challenges", I like how it all works out. The traitor mechanic, one of the original, of there might be one, but not necessarily is done really well in this game. If you like the King Arthur theme, highly recommended. Surprised me by how much I enjoyed this game.

item.name: Sheriff of Nottingham
item.comment: I'm not a huge fan of bluffing games. This was fun, but seemed to take way too long for what it was. You try to sneak goods past whoever is the sheriff over and over. Should be half as long.

item.name: Sherlock Holmes Consulting Detective
item.comment: Love the concept. Simple deduction, well executed. The map and newspaper are great sources of entertainment and clues. The only disappointment is that the story text is very poor, filled with modern colloquialisms and poor grammar, none of which Watson and Holmes had. Needed another thorough edit. Still enjoy the game so far.

item.name: Sid Meier's Civilization: The Board Game
item.comment: I love civ-building and exploring games, but this one falls flat for me. Maybe it's the small board and 3-city limit. I appreciate what this game is trying to do--create a civ-building game with a reasonable play time, but something is missing. After another play, it just doesn't excite me like I hoped. To restrictive of a civ building game.

item.name: Sid Meier's Civilization: The Board Game – Fame and Fortune
item.comment: Some neat ideas in the expansion, like metropolises and great citizen identifies, but it didn't solve the issues I have with the base game. More of the same.

item.name: Sleeping Queens
item.comment: This is a great little card game. A little math, a little mystery, and some good old fairy tale are crafted into this little game. Picked this up for my mom for a Christmas gift and it became one of our favorites when we wanted a quick game to play. The story of how the game was created (by a child with parental assistance) is fantastic! Who could not like the Pancake Queen and her buttery thighs? My wife, mother, and I will play this game any time we need a light filler.

item.name: Smash Up
item.comment: Not for me. It's like someone put all the archetypal themes in a blender and spat out this game. It's just point collecting with random tropes battling each other. Sorry, but Ninjas, bears, wizards, dinosaurs, etc all battling together doesn't work for me. I'd play it, but never request it, nor never purchase it. To each their own.

item.name: Snail's Pace Race
item.comment: Not much of a game, but it's great for very young children. This game teaches dice rolling, piece movement, and planning (Guessing which snail will win or lose). The snails are awesome wooden pieces and the board and dice are equally high quality. Components make the game totally worth it. Will keep this game while the kids are young, but will then pass it along.

item.name: Snakes and Ladders
item.comment: For the kids, but not a good kids game. Good for counting practice and that's about it. How are little ones supposed to figure out the switchback boards? The slides are fun though. My daughter enjoys looking at the board pictures more than playing the game.

item.name: Snatch
item.comment: I like word games, and this one is clever, but there are just other games I'd rather play. Letters are flipped over, words are made, but then you cn steal opponent's words if you make a new, longer word. The tiles are nice.

item.name: The Sneaky Snacky Squirrel Game
item.comment: True kids game. No redeeming value as an adult game. The box, squirrel tongues, and player collecting stumps are neat, but that's about all it has going for it. The spinner of death is such a horrible thing. Why do kids game have such horrid spinners? My daughter does enjoy this, and I will play it with her when she requests. Don't own it, won't, but the library has it.

item.name: Snowdonia
item.wishlistcomment: Good Game. Dry theme. Felt like pushing cubes around. However, it was well designed and I enjoyed the mechanics, especially the randomness element of the weather, which really altered gameplay strategies. Would play again, but don't need to own.

item.name: Sorry!
item.comment: This is one of the few classic older games I do have some sense of nostalgia for. But, I'd rather play parchisi than Sorry.

item.name: Sorry! Sliders
item.comment: Neat idea, but not all that interesting. Slide score. Try to repeat. Some fun.
item.wantpartslist:
Picked up a thrifted copy. Need 3 pieces.
Red Slider Yellow Scoring Pawn Blue Scoring pawn

item.name: Space Empires: 4X
item.comment: Appreciated the game, but didn't love. Wouldn't have seen enough plays to justify keeping it. Solo versions didn't perk my interest either.

item.name: Space Hop
item.comment: Love the trivia cards and solar system board. Not much gameplay running around the board. Still, if I still had it, I'd play it today, but I have no strong desire to reacquire.

item.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel – The Card Game
item.comment: A fun, relatively quick, kill or be killed card game for 1-6. The mechanics work well and the different terrain setups constantly change, keeping things interesting. There's more than just a card game in this.

item.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel – The Card Game – Deathwing Space Marine Pack
item.comment: More marines are nice, but they didn't inherently make them compatible with the other marines, which is a down side. I use them all compiled in my own way.

item.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel – The Card Game – Mission Pack 1
item.comment: Excellent expansion. Always play with these. The more variety of terrain the better.

item.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel – The Card Game: Space Marine Pack 1
item.comment: The two compatible additional marines are nice. Ok expansion.

item.name: Spare Time Bowling
item.comment: Snooze of a dice game. Just go bowling instead.

item.name: Speed
item.comment: Wife loves this quick card game. I really don't, but because it plays so fast, I'm easily talked into a few games. On the plus side, the wife usually wins, which helps her yearly winning percentage.

item.name: Spooky Stairs
item.comment: Good kids game. Not too long, and the ghosts make everyone have a good time.

item.name: Spot it!
item.comment: Great quick pattern/item recognition game. Great for kids.

item.name: Star Realms
item.comment: Not a big fan of deckbuilders, nor do I typically like one one one destruction confrontation, but this one seemed to get it right. A nice quick, back and forth space card game. Found okay at the time, but I keep thinking about it afterwords.

item.name: Star Realms: Crisis – Bases & Battleships
item.comment: Adds more diverse cards. What's not to like? Nothing Earth-shattering, but good nonetheless.

item.name: Star Realms: Crisis – Events
item.comment: Really like the twist the Event cards add. My rating for these may go up over time based on solo and multiplayer plays of this. Easy to get to the table!

item.name: Star Realms: Crisis – Fleets & Fortresses
item.comment: Adds more diverse cards. What's not to like? Nothing Earth-shattering, but good nonetheless.

item.name: Star Realms: Crisis – Heroes
item.comment: I like the different mechanic Heroes adds-allowing them to instantly go into play for a onetime use. I'm a fan.

item.name: Star Trek Trivia Game
item.comment: One of the most interesting trivia games I've played. If you like Star Trek, (Original, TNG, DS9, & Voyager), this is a must have. The board and components are mid to high quality, though we've discovered numerous issues with the editing of the card text. You collect ensignias and they clipped to the bottom of your Trek ship, your player token. Board spaces allow you to steal ensignias from other playes and to lose them during a Borg attack. It's a keeper for me and my wife.

item.name: Star Trek: Catan
item.comment: Retheme of the Settlers of Catan. However, the retheme is excellent. It's not just pasted on like most monopoly rethemes. It mostly make very good, well-thought out sense. The outposts, starships, and starbases are very cool. I also greatly enjoy the one different mechanic, the role-selection cards. It adds an element that not only speeds up gameplay, but is also thematically interesting. I'm impressed. Could of been horrible, but it's very good. If you like Star Trek, this is definitely worth having in any collection.

item.name: Star Trek: The Game
item.comment: I like Star Trek, and this had good production value, but even those that new Star Trek couldn't answer the questions. Too hard. Only played once with the family.

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault
item.comment: So well done. Completely immersive. Beautiful miniatures. I enjoyed this more than Descent. Some of the gameplay changes make it even better than Descent.

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault – Boba Fett Villain Pack
item.comment: Yes please! All these expansions have the same type of content--character(s), side mission, skirmish material. Other than sucking up my money, these are well done. He's a tough one for sure!

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault – Chewbacca Ally Pack
item.comment: Yes please! All these expansions have the same type of content--character(s), side mission, skirmish material. Other than sucking up my money, these are well done.

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault – General Weiss Villain Pack
item.comment: Yes please! All these expansions have the same type of content--character(s), side mission, skirmish material. Other than sucking up my money, these are well done.

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault – Han Solo Ally Pack
item.comment: Yes please! All these expansions have the same type of content--character(s), side mission, skirmish material. Other than sucking up my money, these are well done.

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault – Hired Guns Villain Pack
item.comment: Yes please! All these expansions have the same type of content--character(s), side mission, skirmish material. Other than sucking up my money, these are well done.

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault – IG-88 Villain Pack
item.comment: Yes please! All these expansions have the same type of content--character(s), side mission, skirmish material. Other than sucking up my money, these are well done.

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault – Kayn Somos Villain Pack
item.comment: Yes please! All these expansions have the same type of content--character(s), side mission, skirmish material. Other than sucking up my money, these are well done.

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault – R2-D2 and C-3PO Ally Pack
item.comment: Yes please! All these expansions have the same type of content--character(s), side mission, skirmish material. Other than sucking up my money, these are well done.

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault – Rebel Saboteurs Ally Pack
item.comment: Yes please! All these expansions have the same type of content--character(s), side mission, skirmish material. Other than sucking up my money, these are well done.

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault – Rebel Troopers Ally Pack
item.comment: Yes please! All these expansions have the same type of content--character(s), side mission, skirmish material. Other than sucking up my money, these are well done.

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault – Royal Guard Champion Villain Pack
item.comment: Yes please! All these expansions have the same type of content--character(s), side mission, skirmish material. Other than sucking up my money, these are well done.

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault – Stormtroopers Villain Pack
item.comment: Yes please! All these expansions have the same type of content--character(s), side mission, skirmish material. Other than sucking up my money, these are well done.

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault – Twin Shadows
item.comment: Yes please! All these expansions have the same type of content--character(s), side mission, skirmish material. Other than sucking up my money, these are well done.

item.name: Star Wars: Imperial Assault – Wookiee Warriors Ally Pack
item.comment: Yes please! All these expansions have the same type of content--character(s), side mission, skirmish material. Other than sucking up my money, these are well done.

item.name: Stone Age
item.comment: What a beautiful game. For that reason alone, I'll always keep this. I knew my wife would love the theme, and she did, but the components still make me smile every time I see them--Beautiful board artwork, meeples, shaped wooden resources, food tokens, first-player marker, and more. My wife and I love the dice cup, but unfortunately later versions had smelly leather which ruined it for some gamers. The gameplay for me did start to feel predictable--only a few paths to victory, but after some time away, I've started enjoying this one again. I'll always play when someone asks, but won't suggest it too often. This is a game I would strongly recommend to people for the "game after a gateway game" experience (like Settlers of Cataan or Ticket to Ride).

item.name: Stoner Fluxx
item.comment: Stupid theme to a game that has way to many versions. I really don't mind Fluxx, and many of its themed decks, but its time to move on.

item.name: Stratego
item.comment: I've always enjoyed this relatively simple 2-player game. It's a classic. Never had a lot of people interested in it though, and my wife is not a fan. Gets played about once a year.

item.name: Suburbia
item.wishlistcomment: Nicely designed game. Lots of nice elements thought out--player boards reversible for different play angles, streets graphically designed into city tiles matching up, etc. However, it feels too much like an excerise and not enough like city building. Would definitely play this regularly, but have no desire to own.

item.name: Survive: Escape from Atlantis!
item.comment: Love this game. I rank it a 10. I'd play it all day with anyone. It's quick, straight forward gameplay. Components are very nice. Rules are written well. Sound effects make it better too! There's nothing like feasting on meeple flesh.

item.name: Sushi Go!
item.comment: Nice quick card game. Theme doesn't grab me, and card games are only so so. Would play if someone asked, but wouldn't suggest it.

item.name: Swish
item.comment: Feels like Set, except more complicated and less fun.

item.name: Tales & Games: The Three Little Pigs
Talisman (Revised 4th Edition)
item.comment:
Though I won my first game of this, it was in no way due to any skill. For the first two hours, my character lumbered around the first ring of the board doing very little--failing attacks, failing to increase craft or stength, while other characters did quite well. I did get a gnome. Then I found a raft, went to the interior, and marched to the end. There, I rolled a die for about a hour trying to kill off everyone else.
While I didn't dislike this game, I didn't like it either. More an experience than a game. I had fun, but rolling a die, flipping a card to see what happens, is only mildly interesting. I would play again, but would not suggest it.

item.name: Terror in Meeple City
item.comment: This game was everything I expected. I had lots of fun on my first play. 3 other group members chose to watch instead of start a different game of their own. Flicking and destroying buildings is just too much fun. The variable powers keeps the end game somewhat refreshing. I wonder how long a game like this can stay interesting, but I will want to play again soon.

item.name: Thebes
item.comment: Love the Time-Track element where actions cost time. There is quite a bit or randomness with the pulls out of the bags, but I appreciate the chance. Great game for older kids. Highly Recommended.

item.name: There's a Moose in the House
item.comment: Great title and concept for a kids game. But: No really choice. Game is all luck. Very boring.

item.name: This Game is Bonkers!
item.comment: Silly roll and move random fun. This is a game from my childhood that I keep and my parents' house. My wife and I like to pull it out when we want a quick game and don't want to think too much. There's nothing like getting stuck on the "Go To Lose" side of the board!

item.name: Thunderstone
item.comment: Figured I give Deckbuildres another shot. Received this is trade, and glad I tried it. Neat design, but you're just milling your deck trying to win. Yes, there's strategy in deck milling, but I don't enjoy it very much. Lots of different heroes and monsters helps the interest, but not enough. A game for some folks, but not so much for me.
item.conditiontext: This is a well loved base-game copy. All cards are organized with labeled dividers. Box has wear on edges and corners. Cards show some wear too. Game plays great.

item.name: Tic-Tac-Toe
item.comment: X or O

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment: This is one of those gate way games that get lots of attention. It's okay, but not one of my favorites. The theme feels pasted on. Rather play many other games, but will gladly play this with nongamers to get them interested in other games.

item.name: Timber Tom
item.comment: The 3-D board is awesome. I love the bits, the movement, and the climb for gold. It's just a visually fun game to play. Great family game for slightly older kids.

item.name: Tiny Epic Defenders
item.comment: Nice, quick castle defense game. Enough variability to keep it interesting. Lots of Epic Foes, characters, and the different location abilities is a nice touch too. Still haven't one (on hard, then medium), but come close. Great for a quick 30 minute lunch game. Rulebook could be clearer. Love the wooden devastation markers.

item.name: Tiny Epic Galaxies Deluxe Edition
item.comment: There is a lot I want to like in this game. It's well designed, has good choices, but in the several plays of it, I felt like it was missing something. Maybe that's part of the small design. I enjoy the game, and plan to play it some more, but it is not as exciting as I hoped.

item.name: Tiny Epic Galaxies: Satellites & Super Weapons Mini Expansion
Tokaido
item.comment: Interesting idea, a journey though Japan. I enjoyed my play, but it wasn't something I needed to play again. Not my style of Artwork.

item.name: Torpedo Run!
item.comment: This is a game of my youth! Great 2-player dexterity game. Watching the ships explode is priceless. I'd easily rate this hire, but the components and board are low quality. The plastic pieces broken quickly and the board warped and separated. Still, loads of fun. I'm surprised this hasn't ever been revitalized in a new edition.

item.name: Toss Up!
item.comment: Mildly amusing beanbag game. Good for kids, not for adults.

item.name: Treasure Falls
item.comment: Neat little dexterity game. Kids and adults seem to like it. Box becomes part of the board. Quick and fun.

item.name: Trias
item.comment: I'm a park ranger by profession, geologist by training. Therefore, a game with dinosaur meeples (dinomeeples?) was a must have. The dino-meeples are awesome! I picked this up in a trade and will keep it, but as expected, the gameplay and theme are lacking. When you move continent tiles, the dinosaurs fall into the water and then can swim to a new tile or drown? It makes no sense! Why not stay on the island? This is still what I think, but after another 2-player play, I enjoyed it much more. It's silly, but fun. Gameplay is mostly straight forward, and I like how the new continents evolve. I also thought the 2-player game was not very exciting, and was waiting to player 2 dino-meeple colors with Erin, but this play made me think there was more to the 2-player game. Will definitely continue to evaluate.

item.name: Tribulation
item.comment: Complete and utter math fest. Good for teachers, otherwise would never pull out for a gamenight.

item.name: Triovision
item.comment: Preschool on steroids. Same pattern recognition over and over. Set is infinitely superior.

item.name: Trivial Pursuit
item.comment: Nice board. Rest of the game is a snooze other than for supreme trivia buffs. I appreciate trivia, but these games make me want to stop playing board games.

item.name: Trivial Pursuit: 10th Anniversary
item.comment: Snooze Perhaps it BGG, but as I've been sucked deeper into the hobby, I've really started to detest Trivial Pursuit. There are just better trivia games out there. Still, I'll gladly play when Erin has a hankering--she certainly puts up with all of my game choices. Snooze.

item.name: Trivial Pursuit: 20th Anniversary Edition
item.comment: This version has the most obscure questions I've come across so far. Games stretch out and begun grueling to finish. I enjoy trivia game every so often, but not this one.

item.name: Trivial Pursuit: Best of Genus
item.comment: More of the same. I enjoy this version more than most others.

item.name: Trivial Pursuit: The Lord of the Rings Movie Trilogy Collector's Edition
item.comment: This version of Trivial Pursuit is more interesting than most, though you must be a fan of the Lord of the Rings trilogy. The pawns are nice pewter figurines and the wedges snap into their bases. A Ringwraith can cause you to lose wedges. Unfortunately the question deck is one small box, no where near enough questions to keep this game interesting over time.

item.name: Trivial Pursuit: Volume 6
item.comment: I actually enjoy this version, unlike some of our other TPs. Still, would rather play something else.

item.name: Trouble
item.comment: A roll and move game without the satisfaction of even getting to roll and move. A game I really detest.

item.name: Troyes
item.comment: Interesting work placement/dice placement mechanic. Yet I didn't enjoy the theme and the game became an exercise in management. I can see how strategy players would like this, but it wasn't for me.

item.name: Trust Me
item.comment: I enjoyed this when I was kid, yet when I had a chance to pick this up at a thrift store, I past. I always liked the briefcases, but I think this is a game only older kids with not much experience with interesting games would enjoy. Not interested in playing anymore.

item.name: Tsuro
item.comment: Simple play a tile, move your piece, be the last pawn standing game. Short. Simple. Elegant. Accommodates large groups. Great game.

item.name: Tsuro of the Seas
item.comment: Adds unneeded complexity to a superbly designed, simple game. Original please.

item.name: Twilight Imperium (Third Edition)
item.comment: I love the deepness of this game's mythos. It's not just a game to play, but a story to tell and retell. Yes, this is a monstrously long game, but I've always been partial to completely immersing myself in a world for hours on end. The difficulty is finding other gamers who want to share such a lengthy and immersive experience. High quality components, a modular board, and an inspired turn control system adds to the appeal. A never-ending supply of rule technicalities detracts, but it a game this big and complex, I'd be more surprised if this wasn't the case. This is my style, even if I can't find others to play very often. It's a definite keeper.

item.name: Twilight Imperium (Third Edition): Shattered Empire
item.comment: Great expansion of the game. Keeps the base game right on plugging along. Fixes the Imperial victory point fiasco and provides alternative selection cards. Adds new planets, races, abilities. Most fit in nicely with a basic amount of additional knowledge. Only issue is finding the time to play the game! Otherwise it would be a 10.

item.name: Twixt
item.comment: Meh. The more I explore the world of abstracts, the less I enjoy them (Hive and Cathedral notable exceptions). Perhaps if this game had nice wooden pieces like Cathedral, I might enjoy it more. This is too much like work. Erin like it well enough, but not one I'll request very often. My three year old daughter does enjoy playing with the bits.

item.name: Ultimate Mastermind
item.comment: I somewhat enjoy this logic game, though I'd rather play so many other things first. As this genre is one of Erin's favorites, I'm happy to oblige her. I in fact introduced her to this game.

item.name: Under the Shadow of the Dragon
Unicorns in the Clouds
item.comment:
Walked into a boardgame store on a trip with the kids. 6 year old daughter saw this and asked politely if we good buy it. Kid asking to buy a relatively inexpensive HABA game?
Sure Thing.
And she loves it. Plays it almost every day two weeks after the trip. She learned the rules quick, and now teacher her friends. First game she's ever done that with.
Is this a great game? Nope. Role and Move. Collect crystals, and whoever has the most crystals wins.
However, HABA does this basic game right. Nice wood pony pieces. Nice 3-piece puzzle board. Nice dice. The board flips over so young kids can count their crystals in a line. Plays in 10 minutes, so quick. Just really smart. I will play this every time over other roll and move games like Chutes and Ladders. Rating is a mix of me and my daughters feelings.

item.name: UNO
item.comment: Boring, all luck. Why are so many mainstream games so bad?

item.name: UNO: Harry Potter
item.comment: I really dislike Uno. My wife enjoys it from time to time, so I'll stomach it for her. We dislike the Harry Potter special rules and just play with normal rules.

item.name: Unpub: The Unpublished Card Game
item.comment: This was a moderately fun party game designed specifically for gamers. Each player tries to convince a judge they have the best new board game idea. Good for some laughs. Started to get a little old after a while

item.name: Upwords
item.comment: A clever word game, where you can build atop other letters, but I'd rather play Scrabble.

item.name: Utopia Engine
item.comment: Great Print and Play game. The pencil sketch artwork is superb. Very interesting dice management system. While luck is still a factor, careful play manages the luck very well. Don't expect to win often. I'm glad there are an infinite number of worlds to save. Highly recommended solo-play game.

item.name: Vampire: The Eternal Struggle
item.comment: Not for me. I've fallen out of vampire themed games these past few years.

item.name: Vault Wars
item.comment: Ok game. Didn't grab my excitement, but I'd play again if asked.

item.name: The Very Hungry Caterpillar Card Game
item.comment: I like Eric Carle, the illustrator of these books and this game, and the tin and cards are nice. However, Eric Carle must never have played the game he licensed his illustrations to because I think he would be appalled. The gameplay is horrible and boring, and this is supposed to be a kids game? I can hardly figure this out let alone explain it to my daughter. I'll let my daughter "enjoy" the cards for a few years and then discard this.

item.name: The Very Hungry Caterpillar Game
item.comment: Why do all of the Eric Carle themed games suck? Spin, move, wait. Wait to spin what you need. Wait to spin to move. Better than the card game, but that's not saying much.

item.name: War
item.comment: Old stalwart of long bus rides. Wife and I still play it when we're feeling nostalgic, masochistic, or brain-fried.

item.name: We Didn't Playtest This At All
item.comment: Random and humorous. That's all. Quick Filler. I prefer most Fluxx variants.

item.name: Wildlife Safari
item.comment: Good quick card game with nice animal minatures. Enough strategy to keep interest. Simple enough for older kids. My young daughter has beat me twice and I haven't figured it out yet.

item.name: The Wizard of Oz Trivia Game
item.comment: Must be a Wizard of Oz buff to enjoy this game (like my wife). The rainbow pawns and rainbow scoring pieces are nice. The questions have variable difficulty which is nice. Gameplay is quick, but there's not much replay value. I'll play because my wife like a game every so often. For enthusiasts only.

item.name: Word on the Street
item.comment: Another word game that just doesn't interest me all that much. Pick a card, think of a word that fits in the card category, spell it, shift tiles, and do it all in 30 seconds. Interesting tile shifting mechanics, but that's about it. My mom and wife enjoy this, so I'll keep it around as long as they want. I'll play when they request, but won't request this myself.

item.name: The World of Smog: On Her Majesty's Service
item.comment: Neat game. This theme could have been anything, but the steampunk works great. All the spinning tiles make my head spin. It seems complicated at first, and there is a lot going on, yet the goal is simple. I like how the agents move and are different each game.

item.name: Yahtzee
item.comment: I have never ever enjoyed this game. I just detest it. Never will I ever play.

item.name: Yardmaster Express
item.comment: Very quick card game. Line of card mimics a train well. Not much strategy. Good Luck will often win. Still, good quick filler.

item.name: Yardmaster Express: Caboose Expansion
item.comment: Gives a goal for the game for more points. Nice touch. didn't need to be an expansion. Should have just been in the game.

item.name: Yellowstone
item.comment: This is another game from my childhood that I kept. While not for everyone, my wife and I like pulling this one out about once a year. Though random, this game does do a good job of simulating wildlife in Yellowstone National Park--the abundance or lack of food, the stalking of predators, etc. My biggest gripe is that the board was poorly designed so the poor bison have one more row of hexagons to cross and therefore almost always finish in the back of the pack. My wife and I often each play 2 species. I think this will be a good teaching game when the kids get older.

item.name: Yggdrasil
item.comment: Co-op game based on Norse mythology. If you can't spell the game, how do you expect to be able to play it? Beautiful artwork. Entire game is trying to keep monsters from overwhelming the monster track. I'd play again, but wouldn't request it. Feels like it's missing something.

item.name: Your Money
item.comment: This is a game with tons of math. Yes, you need a calculator. Yet, I find it strangely appealing. You follow a character over an adult lifespan and invest their yearly earnings. Good and bad events happen in both life and the stock market to affect your investments. I liked this as a kid and still like it today with my mom and wife. I pull it out every few years for a game. Not for the typical gamer.

item.name: Zingo!
item.comment: Bingo with common pictures of items--cat, house, foot, dog, etc. Kids love it, which inflates my rating a degree or two. Not a great game, but one kids can play, enjoy, and request. I'll always play it if they request it.

item.name: Zombie Fluxx
item.comment: Good Fluxx game. I've always enjoyed the simplicity of these games, and while they are highly random, sometimes that's exactly what I enjoy. Creepers, (zombies) add an interesting twist, and the thematic goals are amusing. Zombie baseball team anyone?

item.name: Zpocalypse
item.comment: Game does a good job of the relentless push of zombies trying to suck out your brains, but repeated plays feel exactly the same. Survivors are too tongue-in-cheek. Would not get enough plays with my wife or gaming group to justify keeping. Don't regret Kickstarting it, as Greenbrier Games was the most connected to its backers I've ever experienced with Kickstarter.
